text:
Some good points but very misleading conclusions.

1/  Running costs, yes it's CURRENTLY much cheaper but IT WON'T BE IF WE ALL SWITCH TO ELECTRIC CARS.

Becuase A/ the government TAXES the hell out of petrol.  If the entire world switches to electric cars, what do you think the governments response will be?  "Don't worry we'll take the hit, we don't losing all that money."   Hahahaha yeah OK.  They'll find a way of getting it back.  Possibly some elaborate way of taxing electricity usage or mileage, but most likely a massive increase in toll roads or car tax.

(You might argue that at the moment e car taxes are less, but that's only to encourage people to use them to get the emissions down, if the majority migrate to ecars, they will need to get their money back somehow, and they will find a way.)

And B.  Electricity isn't in that great a demand at the moment.  If we all switch to ecars, the demand on the electricity grid and upgrades required will be phenomenal, and this will push the price of electricity up.


2/  Safety - in some ways they are safer yes, but let's not forget in other ways they much more dangerous.

A/  At the moment if you get an electric shock off your car you go "ow" and that's it.  Because it's a 12v humble supply.  If you get an electric shock off an e car it'd enough to kill you.  I know it hasn't happened so far, but there's not a lot of them about so far.  If they ever get ubiquitous to the same popularity as IC engines, the sheer volume of people mean the chances are much higher, especially once they start getting knocked around, poorly maintained, older, etc.

B/  Explosions.  I know you all think petrol cars have petrol tanks which explode easily..... they don't.  That's just something film / tv show makers utilise because it makes for good action watching, but the reality is that it's very difficult to set a petrol tank on fire.  Much more so than a battery pack which can catch fire on its own without any external influence.  And of course if you're comparing it to diesel, well that's near impossilbe to catch fire by accident.  And the fact that people never say "i'll buy a diesel because petrol might explode" tells you how little an issue it is with petrol.  Electric cars on the other hand, well look at what happened to Hammond on Top Gear.  He was lucky to survive, yes the car was well built to protect him but this was in isolated incident, if you get these cars crashing regularly on the motorways/highways, the number of injuries and deaths from exploding batteries is going to skyrocket.  Much higher than petrol/diesel ever caused.  And a few years old with poor maintenance some might even just explode while sitting on charge on your driveway!

text:
So lets not talk about how most of the consumers change their cars in 3-4years tops. Which translates to $5600 spent on the car AFTER buying when it comes to Petrol engines and ~$1800 for EVs. Now after 3.5years you have spent 40+k on THE most economical EV rn (tesla model 3) vs 30+k on an avg gasoline car. So for an EV to be a plausible option for middle class family, it can not be more than $5000 costlier than the petrol variant.
With increase in EVs on the road petrol prices are going to drop too. Making the gap in running costs smaller. EVs might be the future, but that "future" is not now. It will take atleast a decade or two for it to become either mainstream or really "green" (for most countries EV systems are going to gen as much pollution as gasoline cars due to bad energy mix at the grid).
author: akaimal aditya

text: For petrol cars, our planet is the price
author: RR Sharizam

text:
@RR Sharizam EVs are just as bad rn. Unless we use Renewable sources of energy for production of electricity, the difference is not even worth mentioning. 
A country would need to run ~60% of its grid on renewable sources to make EVs even have a noticeable impact on pollution. 
Even disregarding the above points there are many limitations that the media is just skipping to mention when mentioning EVs. Like the fact that China has monopoly on raw materials. The metals required for batteries are miniscule in quantity. The impact on health of driving around or idling in a city full of electric vehicles is still unknown. The wastes from batteries are toxic in nature, recycling is a major milestone to overcome.
One of my friends is working on the field of alternate energy sources and he clearly stated that increasing the potency of batteries is not a difficult problem but sourcing reliable raw materials and disposal is a crazy task. They are advancing at breakneck speeds, but it is still not enough to justify the rollout of EVs right now.
Just stating facts.
author: akaimal aditya

text: @akaimal aditya same to IC engines. Petrol also are not renewable. The difference is: IC engine can only use ¬±20% of energy generated. While EV engine can use up to 90%. That's why it's called EV (energy efficient). It does not claim to be 100% clean energy
author: RR Sharizam

text:
@RR Sharizam whoa. I don't know about your profession, but I hope you are not an engg.
First of all EV means Electric Vehicle.
2nd EVs aee NOT 90% eff. they are less than 70% eff. Induction motor used in the EV can be upto 90% eff. But when that energy is transmitted to the wheel, due to vibration, heat, friction etc only 65-70% of energy remains.
Also, if the energy grid run on less than 40% renewable sources of energy, the overall efficiency of electricity on your wall will be ~35%. Means the efficiency of EVs are effectively around ~23%.
So EVs on avg are 15% more efficient while RUNNING. But the process of manufacturing EVs gives out more pollution add in the toxic wastes from batteries and inefficient infrastructure between grid and walls, they are at most as efficient as gasoline cars or maybe even less.
Hybrid cars are 22-23% efficient IIRC.

text: @Zach B a diesel engine is about 45 percent efficient.  Electricity is generated in a power station at about 35 percent efficiency. Approx. 7 percent is lost in transmission to your home. Ie now 33 percent. Charging the electric car is 85 percent efficient. Ie now 28 percent efficient. And the car's electric motor is approx 85 percent efficient. Ie 23 percent efficient.  23 percent of the (mostly) fossil fuel used to generate the electricity has been used by the car.  This is the same reason natural gas supplied to a home is approx. a quarter the price of electricity supplied to the same home.

text:
Gasoline cars: look cool, sound cool, and are fun. A lot of variety between vehicles when it comes to engines and technology, fully customizable to suit your needs. 

Electric cars: boring designs, lack of diversity in technology between models, uncustomizable, less reliable, and shoved down our throats as the "cars" that will "save the world". Save the world from what? That extremely small percentage of Co2? The same Co2 that plants convert to oxygen? The same plants that the government won't allow farmers and landowners to grow because they're so strict on how much land you can own? And why is the government so strict on us but gives certain countries a free pass to pollute like crazy? The same countries that give us our oil? I'm sorry. I'm no conspiracy theorist, but I can call bullcrap when I see it. And I'm not giving up my awesome cars and awesome engines for what is essentially an adult power wheels without the childhood fun.

text:
The Real Questions Need To Be Answered.
1.) The Battery Pack, How long will the (Battery Pack) last before replacement?
2.) The Battery Pack, How much will it cost to replace it? (Providing The Battery Pack Is Replaceable.)
3.) Electric Motors, The Electric Motor produces heat. How is the heat dissipated?
4.) A (Limited Slip Differential) allows for tighter turning radius. Why use a (Locked Differential) that increases the cars turning
radius?
5.) Lithium Batteries, These Lithium Batteries are great for long runs. However, Why did you not address the fact that Lithium Batteries have a habit of exploding when water is introduced? And why wasn't the fact mentioned that Lithium Batteries can be sensitive to altitude changes and it's results?
author: Arthur Zettel

text:
1.) depending on how often you drive and what method you charge it with (8 hour home charging vs 20-40 minute super charging) and what you consider too low of a range, the battery pack should last you on average 300,000 miles with only a 20% reduction in original range, it is more likely that other components in the battery pack fail before all the cells in the battery degrade beyond use
2.) no solid numbers on cost to replace but here is my guess, at a manufacturing cost of $130kwh a model 3 75kwh batteyr pack has a manufacturing cost of around $10,000, labor and profit for the company might bump it up to $17,000 for a replacement.
3.) Tesla cars have have a glycol/water cooling loop that runs to the computers, batteries, motor, and inverted, they are all cooled equally since all have similar operating temperatures, they run to a small radiator in front of the car near the lower portion.
4.) model S uses open differential.
5. exploding is a strong word, they violently expel flames when in contact with oxygen but have venting holes to prevent the buildup of pressure, i am not aware of the problem with lithium batteries altitude change but there are many instances of them being shipped by plane without problems, do you mean the fire danger that's associated with them during air transportation?
author: Miguel lopez

text:
Electric Cars are Not the future..!   With all the  weapons grade propaganda supporting EV's  we should all face the reality that Electric Vehicles represent less than 1% of Vehicles on American roads...  and there is a very good reason why...! 

World wide,  Electric Vehicles, represent the worst "resale value" , second hand price for any Vehicle type against new price. 
To even quantify  "maintenance"  without Battery replacement Cost (( as a relevant factor )), is beyond bias ; it's a lie....

Most of the problems are associated with " inconvenience " ; this issue  remains after 100 years of Electric Vehicle R & D.
The reality of Recharging time lost and having to plan a trip where a " jerrycan " cannot take you into remote regions.
Long distance Trucks wont be using Battery Electric because the weight of the battery packs "robs the viable payload".! 
Diesel & Gasoline is 100% powerful down to the last drop...  Battery powered Vehicles diminish long before a recharge...

Seriously, there are too many EV disadvantages for Car buyers OR we would see ownership that is more than a novelty.
At this stage , EV's have not gained traction on the Market & wont ; not until, some alternative to lithium is discovered...
The future is likely to be an Electric hybrid with some form of fuel cell that is both efficient and convenient...........

text:
More EV apologetics propaganda.  

Today I stopped by one of our 3 recharging stations on Sunday to time total recharging of an EV.  There were two cars waiting for one of the 4 recharging spaces to open up.  Wait time for the car I was watching first in line was 44 minutes.  It took him another 8 minutes of picking the right combination of dongle and credit card, interspersed with lots of cursing as there is no attendant to help him make it turn the damned thing on after he plugged in his car to the non-standardized charging cable.  After the charging started, I timed the minutes he kept his car connected to partially refill the battery pack.  He disappeared into the venue to wait.  1 hour and 13 minutes later, the car was charged but he didn't return until 15 minutes after it had shut off.  I didn't add that 15 minutes to the charge time.  So, we add 44 minutes wait time to 8 minutes cursing and fighting the chargeport computer plus 73 minutes charging time getting 124 minutes of his life wasted waiting for the miracle to happen.

Let's see how much recharging cost in reality.  I can't tell you exactly because I didn't see the charge to his credit card for power.  But, let's be more realistic and say this guy makes $30/hour for his time at work.  (I could set that at $600/hr if he's a doctor or $1200/hr if he's a lawyer but let's say he works at a local factory as a senior supervisor who can afford a $45,000 car.)  $30 x 2 hours is $60 + charge time charges is a LOT more cost than refilling an ICE car in 3 minutes at Circle K.  No thanks......

Race ya to Atlanta......(c;

text: People always have concerns about charge with electric cars.  It wouldn't bother me leaving home everyday with a full tank.  The induction motor is so much more efficient and they are extremely dependable.  The stator and rotor don't come into physical contact with each other.  Just bearings at each end which are only subjected to rotational forces. Rotating magnetic fields from the stator drives the rotor.  The torque that can be generated is incredible, instant 100% torque.  The electric motor could be braked equally as hard by injecting DC voltage into the stator.  I believe an AC drive would control a cars electric motor.  A drive could be set up to power the motor anyway imaginable by changing certain parameters.  Drive technology in the last 20 years has skyrocketed.  These are so simple, I would imagine any qualified electrician could work on them.

author: Rattaphong Charoenying

text:
@Rattaphong Charoenying alright I'm going to try to make it as clear as possible using some very simple numbers since the whole efficiency and net energy usage could be confusing.

I will be comparing two cars one electric and one that uses a petrol engine at average MPG 24mpg.

1 gallon of gasoline has about 33kwh of chemical energy 

The model 3s 1000lb battery has about 75kwh of chemical electrical energy 

With 75kwh chemical battery the model 3 gets a range of 310 miles

A ICe with 75kwh of gasoline ( about 2.8 gallons of gasoline) would get about 67 miles

So the electric car is 4.6x more efficient, so even if the powerplant that supplied the electricy had the efficiency of 40% it will still mean that the electric car overall takes less energy to move.
author: Miguel lopez

text: @Miguel lopez do you mean 1 gallon of fuel "burned in order to boil the water to get steam to turn the turbine to turn the generator to get electrical power to send to station to store it batteries then send the motor " have more efficiency than just pour into the engine directly?
author: Rattaphong Charoenying

text: @Rattaphong Charoenying yes when you have a steam turbine operating at 40% thermal efficiency and you put in 1000kwh of fuel you will still have 400kwh, line loss has a 7% cost, transformers are nearly zero except for those in a residential area, and batteries have a 12% loss when charging, the motor has a 10% loss, so in this way a electric system has the efficiency of 35% net efficiency but we dont actually use gasoline to produce electricity, we use coal, hydro, wind, natural gas, and nuclear to produce our electricity, how many of these can run inside a car? an engine is designed t use the expansion of gas to produce mechanical motion, but in a chemical reaction heat is the main energy produced, thats why steam turbines usually have a higher efficiency since they are design to use heat and recycle it, combustion engine re use heat only to make burning of the gasoline easier.
author: Miguel lopez

text: @Miguel lopez yes that why i said the advantage is easy to manage because left the waste at the power plant and many ways to generate electricity. However, for me the nuclear power plant seems to be acceptable. The other source have higher costs, especially solar panel is really spent too much space.

text: @Rattaphong Charoenying the nuclear power plant is one of the greenest, safest, and most reliable power source and should be what is powering all electric cars, but expensive to build and maintain, solar is getting cheaper but it will be a while for it to be the king of both kinds of green.

text: Schoell's design is built on a closed-loop system of heating and cooling, which makes the engine much more efficient and produces less waste than previous models. The steam gets so hot that it behaves more like a liquid, which yields more power. It's also less expensive to produce and maintain because it doesn't need a catalytic converter, muffler, oil or a transmission like an internal combustion engine. But best of all, in this era of fossil fuel anxiety, you can use any fuel you like to kick-start the steam process, whether that's gasoline from petroleum or biofuel.
author: Another Settlement needs your help

text: By 1923, Doble's steam cars could be started from cold with the turn of a key and driven off in 40 seconds or less. When the boiler had achieved maximum working pressure, the burner would cut out until pressure had fallen to a minimum level, whereupon it would re-ignite; by this means the car could achieve around 15 miles per gallon (18.8 litres/100 km) of kerosene despite its weight in excess of 5,000 lb (2,268 kg). Ultimately, despite their undoubted qualities, Doble cars failed due to poor company organisation and high initial cost.

author: Miguel lopez

text:
Once upon a time, the steam engine reigned supreme ‚Äî first in trains and heavy tractors, as you well know, but eventually in cars as well. It‚Äôs quite hard to fathom today, but at the turn of the 20th century, more than half the cars in the US were steam-powered. The steam engine was so advanced that, in 1906, a steam car called the Stanley Rocket even held land speed record ‚Äî a heady 127 mph!
Now, you might think that the steam car was only a success because internal combustion engines (ICE) didn‚Äôt exist yet ‚Äî but in actual fact, steam cars and ICE cars were developed contemporaneously. Because engineers already had 100 years of steam engine experience, though, the steam car had a rather large head start. While hand-cranked ICEs were breaking the arms of hapless operators, by 1900 steam cars were already highly automated ‚Äî and, with no clutch or gearbox (steam provides constant pressure, unlike the piston strokes of an ICE), very easy to drive. The one caveat, of course, was that you had to wait a few minutes for the boiler to heat up.In a few short years, though, Henry Ford would come along and change everything. While the steam engine might‚Äôve been technically superior to the ICE, they couldn‚Äôt match the price of mass-produced Fords. Steam car makers tried to shift gears and market their cars as premium, luxury products, but by 1918 the Model T Ford was six times cheaper than a Stanley Steamer (the most popular steam car at the time).With the advent of the electric starter motor in 1912, and continuing advances to the efficiency of ICEs, it wasn‚Äôt long until the steam car vanished from our roads.
author: Another Settlement needs your help

text:
What about us? People in developing countries. There's not even a single public charging station here (in Indonesia)

Let me tell you something. Here, around 35% (my estimation) of all cars and motorbikes in Indonesia, STILL USES CARBURETTORS and there isn't a single electric car in my city (Magelang)

Why they keep using gas engines, especially the carburettered ones? Simple, because of their simplicity, carburettors are simple and easy to fix, everyone with an adequate knowledge of internal combustion engine could fix their own carburettors. Carburettor problems? remove the carburettor, clean it, install it back, done. all DIY, that's how Indonesians do it. Even fuel injection is still considered a new thing here (Particularly for motorbikes)

EVs here are very rare, i doubt EVs have a market share reaching 1% (not even close) and because of their rarity, if something goes wrong, they're incredibly expensive to fix. So for us in developing countries, i think EVs won't be a thing until the next 2 or 3 decades.
author: Daruyos Daruyos

text: No, the recent growth of interest in electric cars is NOT due to any engineering advances, but due entirely to the ignorance of today's generation of young people.  They have absolutely NO knowledge of what the first-gen e-cars were like or what their problems were.  E-cars are also very heavy, due to the high density of both electric motors and batteries, and while their c.g.'s can be very low, their extra weight is still a problem when (a.) stopping or slowing, especially on slick surfaces, and (b.) changing directions.  Steering response degrades as weight increases.

text: Miguel lopez-   There's a serious shortage of technical information in these e-car videos, such as (1.) does the subject e-car have a single motor, sending the power through a differential to the driving wheels, or does it have an induction motor at each driving wheel?  and (2.) does it have a single battery or does it have a high number of small batteries wired together?  Recent TV coverage of storms & flooding show IC cars plowing through water, sometimes as deep as the top of the truck's hood.  How much water depth can an e-car navigate before its' motor(s) or battery(s) are shorted out?  Does this create a strong electrical field surrounding the stalled vehicle, shocking the car's operator when he steps out into the water?  Or is the vehicle now 'dead' and can only be removed via a tow cable?  So when the question, "Which car is better?" is asked, I have to respond with "Under what circumstances?".

text:
Nice summary;  well done!

Perhaps I misread this, but it sounds like you suggested that EVs‚Äô heavy batteries make them harder to take tight turns.  Not clear how you came to that conclusion, if indeed I heard you correctly there.  Heavier vehicles don‚Äôt necessarily have a harder time making tight turns:  True, they have greater inertia, but they also have equally greater frictional force changing their direction.  

Plus, as you subsequently pointed out, with that weight way low in the floor, they have almost no tendency to roll in a turn, and their weight distribution extremely even, so very little tendency to fishtail in a turn.

text:
Miguel Lopez, The reason why electric vehicles never caught on is that they are inferior to the ICE in every way besides instant TQ. 
They are popular now because people believe the false narrative that they are zero emission. the majority of electricity in the united states and many other countries come from coal-burning facilities. Furthermore, the batteries for EVs use materials may be sourced from child slave labor.
author: Hazmatt

text: Matthew Jorgenson um did you forget about better traction control? Less maintenance ( non existant oil changes, brakes that last 2x longer, no transmission fluid, dont have to worry about intake filters, no differential fluid) cheaper refueling 3-4x cheaper to refuel so you save about 6k every 5 years on fuel. Despite misconceptions the majority of the US power grid is not coal, that only counts for 30%, 32% is from natural gas but natural gas is 2 times cleaner than coal, the other power sources are cleaner renewable power plants even though 62% is fossil fuel it still beats ICEs in emissions since the thermal efficiency of a ice engine is laughably bad compared to an induction motor. Lithium is also extracted from salt flats, cobalt is another story.
author: Miguel lopez

text: Miguel lopez, You bring up excellent points, but I would rather have an ICE. But the traction control on a $100,000 Tesla is nothing special. A $100,000 ICE TC would be comparable. It is the instant TQ that gets the EV off the line. The EV is not for me.  I do not want to wait at least two hours every 200 miles. I drive a lot, I have 2007 civic with 465,000 miles. Fluids have only gotten better and can last 15,000 miles for oil and almost 100,000 for transmission. My car sill passes the emission standards with flying colors. Besides, if everyone were to continuously buy the"new and improved" EV every few years, the production in its own would be enough to outweigh the "clean energy" advertised.
author: Hazmatt

text: Matthew Jorgenson it's not just instant torque, due to how induction motors work anytime the RMF frequency is higher then the rotation of the rotor windings it will generate torque that means at very low RPMs the motor can still output near full torque but at the cost of maximum current draw, the traction control is somewhat special because it can be accurately adjusted by a computer since there is not much latency for motor control over the control of pistons, EVs aren't for everyone it will be another 40 years before infastructure and technology will be enough to keep EV's from being an inconvenience to buy over ICE. As for environmental damage EV's will have more of a toxic impact than a climate base one unless technology pushes forward and lithium/cobalt batteries get replaced by something cleaner just like how they replaced lead acid batteries.

text: Hmmm, sounds a bit biased to me.  Considering that electricity in the USA is produced by,  Natural gas (33.8%) Coal (30.4%) Nuclear (19.7%)  how are electric cars environmentally friendly or economical?   Maybe someday, when every roof in the world is made of solar panels and we have an abundance of electricity, and maybe when battery cells are much more compact and contain less toxic metals, then maybe it will become a green option.  And considering that only 16.4% of the world population owns a car, how is an electric car going to be an economical option for the masses?  "It's cheaper to maintain an electric car", really?  I drove my Ford Thunderbird for 4 years and spent $500 total on a radiator and suspension components.  My friend spent $2,500 for a battery replacement on his Toyota Prius, and it's only guaranteed for 4 years, you do the math. I'm sorry but I'm not seeing it, it's been tried many times but petroleum is still king.  The masses (80% of the world) are still struggling to buy a used Toyota Corolla, how are they going to buy a $36-80k Tesla?

text:
1. Power Generation. Electric Cars require some sort of remote power generation system. Internal Combustion does not, thus an electric vehicle can not travel far from civilization where there are no means to recharge it, but an internal combustion vehicle can carry a spare can of fuel in case it is necessary.

2. Vehicle Life. The battery of an electric vehicle is NOT replaceable. The expected lifetime of an electric vehicle is between five and seven years. The expected lifetime of an internal combustion vehicle is upwards of thirty years or more if well cared for. 

3. More toxic/hazardous chemicals are required for the construction of an electric vehicle vice an internal combustion vehicle, as well as the environmentally damaging process of strip mining to get the lithium (which is a toxic substance) for the batteries.

I just don't think that electrics are really that great.

text:
The part about friction is utter nonsense. The coefficient doesn't change at all, that's why it's a coefficient.
Actual friction increases however, because of the higher weight (friction= coefficient*weight).
The higher weight might cause other issues when cornering. The higher mass simply requires more force to turn or stop (and more energy to speed up) Besides this the increased friction adds some inefficiency.

text:
Overall you got it right, in your final analysis--- EVs are better--- but you did get it wrong in several respects, and did miss a few points as well.

You did say EVs do not require a transmission, but you shoukd have also pointed out that they need no reverse gear to back up--- it only requires a change in power flow... providing a massive savings in weight, and far greater simplicity--- depending on what qualifies as a "part" (is a universal joint a "part", or a collection of a dozen or so individual ball or needle bearings, for instance), an EV can get by with as few as FIVE moving parts, such as you have in the Corbin Sparrow, perhaps not more than twenty moving  parts in the entire drive train.  This is compared to an ICE which can have several thousand moving parts including pistons, cranks, valves, springs, belts, lifters, rockers, gears, fuel pumps, torque converters, etc.

Any moving part requires energy to keep it moving, and results in energy loss due to friction.  Reciprocating parts waste far more energy than parts rotating on their own center of gravity, and far, far more energy losses when considering square FEET of metal-against-metal friction (aided somewhat by lubricants).

The moving parts in an EV all rotate on their own center of gravity, and have infinitesimally less metal-to-metal contact, such as the ball or needle bearings at each end of the electric motor drive shaft, which altogether only amount to a single square inch or so.

Your single greatest error, though, is in trying to compare the energy potential in a gallon of gasoline to a battery!

Yes, there is lots of energy potential in gasoline, but most of it is lost as chemical heat, friction heat, light, vibration, reciprocating motion, etc. After adding up all the parasitic energy losses, a battery-powered car is PRESENTLY just a little less efficient compared to an ICE car, and since billions are being spent yearly on battery chemistry at more than five dozen researh labs, universities, and even privately funded individuals, we most certainly have not exhausted all the possibilities regarding battery energy density.

If the comparisin of ICE and EV battery systems were as bad as you indicate, a Tesla Roadster would not be able to drive more than 620 miles on a single charge while driving at 60 mph... it has an efficiency rating of about 200 mpg equivalent... 0-60 mph of 1.9 seconds... and a top speed of 260 mph or so.

A Chevy Bolt has a real-world range of more than 300 miles, an EPA rating of 119 MPGe, and is nearly as inexpensive as a comparable ICE car.

The first microwave ovens I saw in the mid-1970's cost about $4000.; they were rather pathetic, with no features such as turntables, touch screens or electronic timers--- they relied on a mechanical wind-up timer, like a cheap kitchen egg timer.  The last time I priced a microwave oven, they were about $40, had foir times the energy output, and had all the bells and whistles.  Computer CPUs, hard drives, digital screens, etc., have gone through similar price drops... as have digital watches, cell phones, etc.  The first digital watch I saw was a Seiko for $1009.  Several years ago I bought a pair of matching, men's and women's watches for ONE DOLLAR at a 99 cent store.

EVs will not drop by that much, but their batteries are bound to plummet in price, making EVs far cheaper than ICE cars, with massively better performance, efficiency, and lack of need for service such as ICE cars require today.  ICE cars will NOT be able to compete at all very soon.

text:
There's no ionizing radiation from batteries (not unless you have a radioactive isotope in them -which would be an impurity if there was and, if in any appreciable levels would shorten the life of the battery - why these batteries are expensive is that purity of the chemistry needs to be extremely high).
Any EM radiated during discharging is also negligible, though the wiring could potentially have some induced EM coming from the motor driver circuitry (there's a lot of shielding and chokes in the components, so even that would be negligible).

text:
Miguel lopez EVs aren't any better for the environment than are ICE. The reason is that according to the IEA, natural gas will be by far the number one way the world makes electricity in 2040. This means going forward EVs will be powered by natural gas more than anything else.

On the other hand CO2 will not likely be a problem in the future, scientists have already developed genetically modified cork trees that are capable of completely absorbing all the extra CO2 we make.

I'm against the political aspects of carbon tax, and all that stuff. Mainly because the world cannot possibly use less carbon, so it's basically a tax grab.

The reason why I prefer ICE, is because they are more fun to drive.

Additionally, upgrading the electrical grid, for EVs, will cost at least a trillion dollars, a cost that will be passed onto regular people. The result will be electric bills bigger than mortgage payments.

text:
There is some important information missing in this, especially considering energy storage and efficient use of said storage.
for example, in a Tesla Model S the actual energy density is only 209,1 Wh/kg due to the requiered cooling and 20% DoD cutting into the usuably energy. But there is a very important factor that changes the value of both systems, and that is engine efficiency. Most motors in electric car are around 90% efficiency, that means ~90% is converted to kinetic energy, the remaining 10% is waste energy in heat. On a combustion engine thats another story, todays high efficiency combustion engines work around 40% efficiency, older models or power over efficiency models can even be below 30%. So say we use your 250vs1200 values, in terms of efficient Wh/kg its around 225 vs 4800. Sounds a bit les crazy doesnt it?

text:
This is a really good video, but it over exaggerated the weight and the cornering performance issue.

The Tesla Model S has a range of up to 315 miles and weights about the same as other cars its size. ¬†

Jaguar XF 5071 lbs
Opel Astra 3038-3505 lbs
MB S-Class 4343-4892 lbs
Tesla Model S 4,469 to 4,941 lbs
Porsche Panamera S 3980-4560 lbs

It would be false to say that corning force is reduced "considerably" because the Model S has tested .91 g in the skidpad by the major magazines. ¬†Remember the Model S low center of gravity helps cornering. ¬†Tire coefficient of friction is dependent on tire loading (tire load sensitivity), but it is not that sensitive and not critical for road cars. ¬†The video even shows a graph of tire load sensitivity and the graph even shows the slop is not that steep. ¬†It is a factor, but very small.

text:
Electric vehicles are super expensive to buy brand new. So you‚Äôre not really saving money from the start and you‚Äôd have to own one for several years to get your money‚Äôs worth. Even with govt incentives while buying. 
*Also you need a garage to charge overnight at home.

text: Please don't refer to the Model S as a sports car, apart from bolting in a straight line to 60 to 80 MPH, it handles corners poorly when compared to road legal racing brands like Aston Martin, e.t.c, the fun in a Model S really all happens under 80MPH and no sharpe turns...the car is not designed to be nimble, agile and dynamic, its 2 metric tones after all!...it is not a fighter jet :-P...I ¬†believe Hybrid technology for the next decade or so will be on the forefront of the top performing vehicles....using electric motors to propel the machine to 0-60 as quick as a Model S then the ICE kicks in to take you up the MPH strip where electric motors simply can't compete at the moment and likely for the next decade...we all know right now electric cars can't reach higher speeds as fast as ICE. ¬†I think Model S reaches 155mph in about 27 seconds where a McLaren will do it in 17 and then power on to 208mph if required. ¬†Right now EV's can't hold their high or top speeds for very long without the battery, the stator or the controller overheating, or the battery draining quickly...there are some fundamental technological challenges which will need to be overcome for EV's to achieve this (hence the decade prediction)....so I see Hybrids like McLaren P1 as the future for Sport / Performance cars. ¬†Ultimately technology is an evolution and we should apply the best of each school...there are some who would like to polarise the issue EV vs ICE, I personally think when they are combined they destroy their exclusive opponents....unless your a tree hugging, sandal recycling hippy ;-) in which case you shouldn't be driving any car full stop :-P

text: What about repair costs to the motor and batteries and all of the onboard electronics in the EV vehicles? Do they compare to repair costs to IC engines? My friend bought a Tesla from the insurance company salvage vehicles and after doing all of the repairs to it with new paint (it was mostly cosmetic with suspension damage and airbags) and getting all of the inspections done and passing them (in my province you need 3) and after towing it around everywhere, The Tesla car Company refused to "unlock" the vehicle's computer. Tesla said no, the car will never see the road again. This is after the government inspections deemed it safe again for road use. Tesla said no. Is this the future of our personal transportation? No more do-it-yourself capabilities? Be careful what you wish for. Gone will be our independence. And if you think that once they switch to all electric vehicles that we will no longer be dependent on oil - think again, crude is needed to make the rubber, plastic, electronics, carpets, headlights, taillights, body panels and parts on each EV. text:
Only a few issues i saw in the video

1. You pointed at a resonator and not a catalytic converter, but that looks to be a graphical problem as there was no catalytic converter :-P

2. Weight does not affect the car's handling if the suspension and wheels are engineered properly for the car. Take the BMW X5 M vs the M5 with similar track times and even study the Bugatti Veyron and its power to weight ratio vs track times of other hyper/super cars. The coefficient of friction should only affect the rolling resistance.

3. A transmission is not used to "transfer the motion to the drive wheels", it is used to transfer gearing from the engine to the drive wheels

4. not all waste heat is from the motor in a EV, you also get waste heat (energy) from chemical transfer of electricity to and from the batteries (which is covered later in the video) that should be taken into account as a whole

5. You have to take into account that electricity has a bit of waste to not only reach its destination, but then also charge batteries, and you if store batteries to charge your vehicle than you will further waste more energy. On top of that, there is also self-discharge that has to be taken into account. Think of it as a storage tax and the closer they get to 100% charge the more it will self-discharge

6. Not only is petrol much more energy dense (as stated in the video), but even more important.. it's much cheaper to store and doesn't have any further waste/degradation when moving around. Unless you can count the transportation of fuel as waste, and crude oil shipments, drilling, and refinement lol.

author: Thimmanna C

text:
things also worth mentioning:
1. You can charge your EV at home on your power plug. While with your ICE you have to drive to a gas station first. Thus, if you travel only short distances every day, you practically never have to really "wait" for your car to recharge. You do this over night, when you're home and sleeping. And that changes the equation from having to find and drive to a gas station plus waiting there 5 minutes or more (if you're not the only one) compared to the couple seconds effort for (un-)plugging an EV every other week or so. With a range of about 400km (Tesla Model S), and a 5 day workweek that means every two weeks (400km per 10 days = 40 km/day should be good) you have a couple seconds effort.

2. The fuel efficiency for an ICE is currently at a max of 14% and will not get any better in the near future (this technology is maxed out). An EV charged from local power network already has 34% efficiency (given the power is generated in an oil power plant) and if you can guarantee that the power comes from regenerative energy source, like water, wind and solar, it gets up to even 79%. If you own your own a solar roof and generate the charging power yourself, you even have 84% efficiency. So when it comes to environment .. your EV is much "greener" than any ICE.

text:
The key(s) in the conversion to electro-motive vehicles [currently] is the same reason argued for the building of cities... along with an electrical-service grid, indoor plumbing and underground sewage-systems: the creation of a system of convenience--along with application of learned habit of their usage--for improvement of living-conditions. 

Look at it this way: We already make habit of charging our cellphones & tablets at every opportunity during non-usage, so it we apply the same to an electric-vehicle--say: while we're at home for the evening/night, as it sits parked in our driveway or garage--what little of it's total range capability that's actually spent on-average daily will be conveniently & quickly replenished while we go about the rest of our daily lives, leaving it fully "at-the-ready" for it's next usage... regardless of how much less or greater that day's total range usage may be.

text: I question a statement from this video at 3:15.  "The poor energy density of the battery produces a huge weight penalty to the electric car.  The huge weight of the car reduces the coefficient of friction between the tire and road considerably, making cornering difficult."  I believe a heavier car would actually have MORE frictional contact with the ground than a lighter car.  It is harder to slide two wooden blocks against each other if they are clamped together under high pressure, than if they are just lightly touching.  So if a heavier car does have more trouble turning sharply ("cornering"), this would be due to the greater centrifugal force due to its greater mass; although the greater frictional contact of the tires with the road might offset this.

text:
the worst problem with producing electric cars is that, compared to a IC engine, the electric car will cause more CO2 to be produced. Plus the problems with the lithium batteries when they day, is that they can't be recycled. Not to mention the cost and effort of mining lithium is a very difficult task and requires a lot of machinery, which burn gas, which produces more CO2. Also, when you have to charge an electric car, you're going to use more electricity from the outlet, which means electric companies will have to build more plants to produce more electricity by burning coal and oil.

bottom line, electric cars are not a good option, they might be in the future, but not now.
author: VishousCat

text:
Not really. Apples to apples, the CO2 production in the manufacture is about the same - that part is true. It's the CO2 created during the lifetime of the vehicle. A typical ICE loses 95% of it's energy to waste heat and friction (that is, for every Liter of petrol, you burn 950mL as pure waste!). Gasoline requires crude oil drilling+cracking, and of course, transport - which ALSO requires a lot of energy. On the contrary, even with power-line transmission and other conversion losses @20%, you still come out, energy wise, better off in distribution - add to that the 95+% conversion efficiency of a 3 phase motor (including control electronics). 
Even if the grid electricity is all sourced from fossil fuels, the end result is LESS CO2 from operation lifetime, not more.

text: IC cars are at this time much, MUCH better.    The cost of Li-ion batteries currently used in EVs is so high because of material processing and limited sourcing that you can only put a very limited mass of batteries in the car, and therefore the range is short.   If you use the advertised range often then the battery will degrade because it has a limited cycle life.   So today we have the Tesla model S which costs 90K and if you use the advertised range of 300 miles the battery can be recharged only 500 times and then it begins to fail and the range drops off dramatically.    For one third the price of that car you can get a great IC car which you can fuel up with gasoline or diesel anywhere and it takes only about three minutes.   If you can find a charging station for your Tesla it will take over 20 minutes, and fast charging again will damage the battery.   To preserve the battery you have to recharge it slowly over several hours.    There is just no comparision for cost and convenience.   Now if you used a different battery all bets are off.    There might be a cheaper battery in the future which is solid state, and that could change everything.   Also if someone were to use cheaper but heavier batteries like NiCad or similar ones then you could add more battery mass and have more range.   You could also work out a battery swapping system instead of high current thirty minute recharges.    There are several possible solutions but Tesla is not doing any of them because their buyers are rich and stupid enthusiasts who will pay 90K for a car they can't make trips in and they will nurse the battery by not using it's range and they still say they are happy because they are emotional morons and are not making rational decisions.   But the truth is few decisions about cars are rational, and most are based on emotion...  That's why I drive a 450 hp Mercedes.

text:
Given my somewhat poor experience with battery powered tools, I do not have a lot of confidence in long term battery life.  Most electric car write-ups talk of batteries lasting 100,000mi and some (wish) talk of 200,000mi.  What they don't speak of is longevity.  Given 15,000mi/yr basis results in 6.7years.  No problem if you trade in every 3-5yrs. What about when you retire and buying power is reduced?   My current autos are 16, 17 and 28yrs old...original engines.  Also, what happens to the battery packs if you do not drive each vehicle regularly - shorter battery life?  At what rate?  
Youtube is full of old engines being restarted after sitting for years simply by changing the gas/fluids/battery ($50-$100).   Beats the hell out of $3500-$5000 battery replacement...which has to be done at the dealer!!

text: Your explanation of the AC motor being lighter is poor. The reason it has such good power/weight ratio is because it is a high frequency design like what is used in aircraft hydraulic pumps (they use 400 Hertz AC induction motors) . It takes less copper and iron for high frequency designs of transformers and AC motors. Just take apart your computer power supply to see how tiny the transformer is inside them, yet they can be rated at 300 to 1000 watts. A 50/60 Hertz transformer of the same power level would be HUGE and weigh enough to crush your fingers or toes if you dropped it.

text:
mxNoob tell you what, I'll give you a list of some common components used  in the making of Li-Ion batteries and you can look up related MSDS data after that go look-up MSDS data for all the components that are used in gasoline / diesel fuels as well as crude oil. 
Here we  go: Sphherical graphite, Lithium carbonate, other metal salt or salts depending on Li-Ion Types ( aluminium oxide, manganese oxides, cobalt oxide, iron phosphate, manganese phosphate, titanium oxide, nickel oxide,... Etc.), LiPF6, organic solvents (search for organic solvents used in Li-Ion batteries), copper, aluminium,... Etc.
author: Milan Swoboda

text: Yes I know that fossil fuels are no better containing things like benzine, heavy metals, etc. The point was that Li-ion batteries arent without their own flaws as well. Also, theres still the safety factor: How safe are those batteries? Obviously gas tanks can explode and are dangerous, but what happens if a battery bank is damaged? Does it just leak electrolyte or does it actually explode? At least with gas tanks, theyre normally behind everything, but looking at the video it looks like the entire undercarrage of an electric car is one big battery
author: Sarah and Skye

text:
Certainly there are some things in Li-Ion batteries that are not "healthy" but they are not even close to the negative environmental impact level of those in petrol products.
As for safety,  first off the Li-Ion rechargeable battery group contains many different types  of electrolyte, anode and cathode make-ups and there are big differences in calendar life, cycle life,  energy density and other properties between these types.  Also the property on risk of thermal runaway differs greatly between the Li-Ion types so you cannot do a direct risk correlation between a cell phone battery to those used in an EV unless you can be sure that they are the exact same Li-Ion types. 
Now generally Li-Ion batteries do not explode since their casing is designed to vent over pressure so I would say that explosions are unlikely. The higher risk is the possibility of a thermal run-way which generates large amounts of heat but that requires certain conditions and is not something that just happens out of the blue without some prior warning signs.  The battery management system in EV batteries keeps tight control to prevent and detect thermal run away conditions so also there the risk is relatively low. Furthermore the batteries are enclosed in structurally strong metal container which minimizes physical damage to the battery packs inside and it also helps contain the heat for some time in rare case that a thermal run-away occurs.
author: Milan Swoboda

text: I have 3 kids who commute 120 km each  per day in all kinds of conditions. weather can be anywhere from -40f to +100f in blinding snow storms and extreme cross winds, on a single lane highway and partially on a gravel road.  I doubt that they could commute in an electric car. Will electric cars make 250000k in their lifetime?  how long does the battery last?    A costly transmission could be cheap compared to a very costly battery pack.
author: AL M

text:
A chevrolet bolt or tesla model 3 would be excellent for those temperatures and range. Electric cars got a really powerful heater, able to make the car ice free in 2-3 minutes, or program it to start heating a few minutes before you travel(using electricity from your house). 
The batteries will degrade slightly over time, but its about 1% per 30,000 km. Electric cars also have unused capacity(about 10-15% top and bottom) that prevents it from being fully charged or drained completely. 
How long the battery last depends on how much capacity you bought over what you need. It will last for a very long time if you buy a car with 400km range, when you only need 200km. The battery will last till you're unable to drive 200km with it.

text: There is one burning question that I have. The main thing keeping electric engines from taking the dominant role in transportation is the slow charging compared to fill-ups.  Why the hell isn't Hydrogen more of a thing? We have a few on the streets here in California. Shouldn't a Hydrogen cell vehicle eliminate the major downside of owning an electric vehicle? I do understand that the initial start-up is expensive. Is it that it takes too much energy to make hydrogen? Renewable fuel sources are a thing.
author: esqueue

text:
The worldwide production of Hydrogen is derived from approx. 48% Natural Gas, 30% Oil, 18% Coal and just 4% Electrolysis of Water.  The top 3 production methods are done via steam reformation which creates large quantities of CO2 as a byproduct but they are cheaper than the electrolysis of water but still more expensive than Gasoline.  I think pricing of the high purity and highly compressed Hydrogen which is required for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles runs at something like 10 to 16 USD at the pump ( if you find one ).  So for example  with a Toyota Mirai, which has a 5kg Hydrogen capacity, you'd pay  between 50 to 80 USD for a complete fill and that gets you about 312 miles (EPA rating). 
Furthermore  fuel cell vehicles are electric vehicles with a smaller battery pack that have a fuel cell added on so they are hybrid vehicles.  This adds complexity, maintenance  and cost. Fuel cells also do not last forever and output degrades over time. Normal life expectancy of a Hydrogen FC is something like 2000 hours  (~60K miles) but they install over capacity fuel cells in the vehicles to achieve around 5000 hours (~150K miles) before requiring replacement.  
Oh and just in case you'd like to generate Hydrogen at home via electrolysis with Solar panels so that you can refuel your FCV  at home like you could with an all electric BEV: estimate about 75-110 Kw of electricity required for 1kg worth of high purity Hydrogen so you'd have to invest in a rather large solar system + electrolysis apparatus + purifying system + high pressure compression and storage system + maintenance needed of that system.  I doubt you'd get a positive ROI on such a small scale system in a life time  ;)

text:
Why don't you mention the amount of rare ressources to build an electric car: lithium for the battery or neodymium for the eletric motor for example...
I guess it's a short range solution in many ways and only eco friendly localy.
While manufacturing an electric car a huge amount of energy is needed and for that the co2-emission rate skyrockets. While mining and processing rare metals toxic and even radioactive contamination may occure. Some studies figured out, that in comparison you can drive a normal petrol car several years to balance out the amount of energy that is used to build and run an electric one. The battery loses capacity over time so it needs to be changed. And how are these components recycled? I've never heard of an shrinking fuel tank. If everyone would drive an electric car, how do we cope with the excessive demand of energy? Most of our energy is still produced in nuclear and coal power plants which has to be considered as well. You don't just plug a cable into a wall and the power comes magically out of nowhere. And the infrastructure for a wide range net of charging stations doesn't even exist rudimentary. You have to transport the electricity via cable to every station and deal with the energy loss at a great distance. So a transformer is needed on every station, producing a huge amount of heat. And if a bigger number of people try to charge up their cars simultaneously, I don't think the electric infrastracture can handle the sudden increase in demand.
If you run out of petrol you can take a jerry can, walk to a gas station and refuel you car. If you electric pile of crap gets stuck, good luck...

author: rohit saju

text:
+rohit saju Incorrect because there cannot be a clear cut answer on this since the charging time will depend on the battery charge level between start and end of charge,  the max. charging output of the on-board charger or output limitations of the AC connection in case of Level 1 & 2 charging,  the  max. output of Level 3 charging (DC fast, Super Charger) if that is used and the temperature or charger level of the battery (charging rate decreases with hot ,cold battery conditions and near full battery charge level) 
So with a level 1 charger you may add a couple  miles/km of range per hour of charging time to your battery whereas you might get around  150 miles/240 km additional range with a level 3 charger on a 30 minute charge.

text: It IS emotional. You're right. The sound is just one component of it. The smell of a gas station is another. It reminds you of road trips with your family. It reminds us of those first dates -- in a car -- with that special, wonderful girl. We all enjoyed the independence and privacy a car gave us -- and our girls -- growing up. Cherished memories. Those wonderful days were spent in cars that had a certain sound, feel and smell. Pure, deep emotion. But if we all grew up with electric cars, we'd all have a deep emotional bond for electric cars, and if someone came up with a car that used internal combustion as propulsion, we'd all be horrified at how loud,  smelly, dirty, oily and slow it was, and how much more maintenance is required.
author: Alexander Hamilton

text: According to http://www.fuelly.com/car/ford/f-150/1978  Your pickup gets around 10 miles a gallon of gas. Dude. That's bad. I commute a stupidly long distance: 82 mile one way. 164 one-day total. I know. I'm an idiot. I had a PT Cruiser. 23 miles a gallon. That got expensive. So I got a Honda CR-Z. 36 mpg. Better. Still, I was paying something like $3,040 over the course of my 180 runs a year. I became obsessed with my fuel bill. I learned how to "Hypermile", which means I learned how to drive REALLLLLLY SLOOOOOOLY, and I could get it up to 40 mpg for months at a time. But that got old. Then, I saw the TESLA Model S.  Amazing. Great range, and good enough for me. Too expensive. Then I saw the Chevy Bolt EV.  Great range: 250. But I didn't know how expensive electricity is. Turns out, it's about 1/3 the cost of gasoline, compared to my Honda. But then I got solar panels put up. Now my electricity bill is effectively Zero.  Anyway, back when I was spending $3,000 a year on gasoline, I was getting 36 mpg.  If I had to make my run in your 1978 F-150, i'd have to burn up 18 gallons of gasoline, which would burn up the whole gas tank, and that would cost me - $65.70 just for one day. 180 runs times $65.70 is an astonishing $11,870.  WOW!  ELEVEN THOUSAND, EIGHT HUNDRED and SEVENTY!  FUCK THAT! But if I had your F-150 for 10 years, I would have to spend $111,870 on gasoline. ONE HUNDRED AND ELEVEN THOUSAND, EIGHT-HUNDRED AND SEVENTY!    For me? Zero. In fact, because of my solar panels -- which will be paid off in 7 years -- I'll actually SAVE on my electricity bill, which will basically be like getting a RAISE. $111,870. Holy SHIT that's a lot of money.  Wow.

text:
+Ananda chatterjee ,  maybe where you live it would be more likely to be coal that is used to generate the electricity but in other locations of this world it might be natural gas, nuclear, wind, water, solar or a combination of them that generate the electricity that power the EV.
-  As for mining lithium not so eco friendly,  well again you cannot throw the whole world into one bucket, some countries where the mining is done do not have or enforce environmental protection standards but that does not apply to all countries.  Oil exploration and drilling is even less eco friendly and an oil spill in the ocean will be far more disastrous than lithium carbonate being spilled on the ground.
- Hydrogen is not available in its elemental form on planet earth instead it is bound in molecules to other elements therefore Hydrogen cannot be harvested and must be produced.  The problem is that the hydrogen bond is very strong in molecules and a large amount of energy is needed to break this bond thus making hydrogen expensive to produce therefore not competitive especially if used in an IC engine which adds a low operating efficiency to the mix.  The majority of Hydrogen on the world market is produced by steam reformation of natural gas by the petrol industry and this process releases lots and lots of CO2 as a by product so not so eco friendly either.

author: Lukas Dzunko

text:
When Ford introduced the Model T there were no gas stations. The inconvenience of buying fuel kept this type of argument going for a while... Not a long while though. That was back in 1908. 

If you the flat you are referring to was in the gentrified section of Boston many a renter has forgone car ownership due to the lack of free parking or the cost. They cab it, Uber it, Zip car it, or use public transit. A deeded parking spot topped $100,000.00 several years back. If you can afford that kind of cash for a parking spot, getting juice to it seems like a small hurdle. For the rest cost and convenience is a higher hurdle. Fueling is not the issue. 

The Tesla Roadster was introduced in 2008 with no super chargers. Then came the Model S in 2012. To support adoption Tesla started to buildout their super charging network. The beginning of 2012 there were 0. By the end of 2017 their goal is 15,000.

Thats just one manufacturer. Someone had to start the ball rolling. Now go and take a look at what VW, BMW, Volvo, Renault, Nissan.... Well, that list gets rather long. Some the the old manufactures will drag their feet whining the whole way. If they dig in too deep, one day in the not too distant future they will look up to see the EV manufactures placing a headstone on their corporate grave. Here lay the once mighty king(s) of combustion.

The problem you point to is currently being address.

author: Lukas Dzunko

text:
At this point in time no one is forcing you to turn in your gas or diesel powered car, and that is not likely to change. The same was true for the horse and carriage. The switch from horse and carriage actually happened rather quickly in spite of the lack of an infrastructure. It started in the larger cities. One reason was pollution. Old consisted cities like Boston and New York, you would be ankle deep in horse crap. In the older sections of Charleston there are still cast iron shoe scrappers on the bottom step. The filth brought flies and disease. There was a lot of horses, so there was a lot of filth. By the 1940's the horse and cart was already a novelty. 

You can not scrape todays pollution off your shoes, you can smell it though. It is a very real hazard to your health as well as the health and welfare of the masses. While some will refuse to believe the facts, that will not change them. It will force governments to action. Don't like the old horse vs. car example...

The transportation industry as well as the utility industry has entered the world of high tech. What the smart phone did to the cell phone, the EV will do to the ICE, granted for very different reasons. The term is called disruption. Disruption does not allow for the slow moving evolution of the mature established players. It eats their lunch and dines on their profits while the old guard continues to serve yesterdays market.

I understand the romantic love many have for cars. I drove mussel cars and rebuilt a corvette back in the 1970's. I have owned sports car's, pickup trucks, dirt bikes, jet skies and power boats. I'm not 22 and can't relate to you. My engineering background is in the computer industry. I have lived and died riding the rollercoaster disruption curve. 

The early adopter phase has ended. Economics will now replace their more mobil reasons. Just as single occupant cars are banned from the carpool lane, soon diesel cars will be banned from congested cities. Then, the next step will be any ICE. Soon cost and convenience will motivate this change.

You may choose to stick with your ICE. That is your choice. No matter how slick a YouTube presentation might be, it will not change this reality.
author: tropicalday88

text:
+tropicalday88 living in a flat and having an EV is a big hurdle. Why choose an EV if you have public transport? That is better for the environment.

Do you know what bad for the health is? Sitting at 95F in the office without climate and bad air and to work for 8 hours in such conditions and to be productive. What is the government doing about that? Pollution doesn't only come from cars, there are bigger polluters. But it is easy to blame ICE cars.

text:
I'm a big fan of public transportation. In some cities its great, in some well it's fair to poor. Portland has a great story in terms of payback for their investment. The current high hurdle apartment dwellers face in terms of charging will change. In fact it is in some areas. Yes, charging stations are not ubiquitous. That said charging is not an insurmountable problem for most in todays world. The mid-tear market is really just getting started and that will bring significant change. Still plenty of time to enjoy filling up your gas tank.

As for your second point regarding a piss poor work environment, well that is a bit off topic. Sounds like you are working in a sweatshop. I hope you are well compensated for your efforts. Working in an automotive repair shop really sucks as well. Hot as hell in the summer and freeze your ass off in the winter. Many countries / states have regulations for work environments. You might want to do a little research. You might have a case, or just place an anonymous call in to that regulatory agency and ask for an inspection.

Yes, their are bigger polluters, like say the utility industries. Change is happening their at a rapid rate as well. Solar, wind, as well as other renewables. Older large building, yes, they are a problem. Check out what the New York Empire State Building has done in that regard. Check out Lead Certification for buildings. Much is being done. Enough, well no, their is no magic wand, their is however some great work being done and you have to persevere. As for ICE's being easy to blame? Well thats because they number in the millions and every step reqiired to find and refine fuel to run them is toxic.

author: Lukas Dzunko

text:
There definitely is a replacement for the ICE. It is the EV, this market will rapidly expand. There is a difference between I am not happy with the alternative, or I'm not happy with the offerings currently available and it's inevitable replacement. There is no satisfactory argument for a positional bias that liquid fuels rule in spite of all its liabilities. That does not make that position true.

Fueling positional bias are multibillion dollar corporations. Mainly the old automotive and petroleum industries fueled with dated facts. They know this change is inevitable. They even know the perils of continued investment in hydrocarbon based transport. It's the threat to quarterly profits and the obsolete internal culture that will lead to billions of dollars in stranded assets. In their eyes that will be someone else's problem. They will walk out rich. Mainly stock holders and individuals that were slow to adapt will be stuck with obsolete technology sitting in their garage or an investment portfolio thats crashed. They will be the ones left to feel the pain. Darwin made a rather salient observation regarding the failure to adapt.

Britain, France, well much of Europe are expanding DC fast charging stations. Are you having trouble finding them? There's an app for that. If a startup (Tesla) can go from 0 fast charging stations in 2012 to 17,000 by the end of this year, can you imaging how many the old established automotive manufacturers could install in a fraction of time. I wouldn't wait for them. Every gas station has electricity, and they are starting to get on board. As well as grocery stores, shopping malls, rest stops, hotels, airports, and yes, corporations. Even condo owners with deeded parking. If you are willing to look, you will see.

That may not change how you feel about it. Your position might never change. Everything else will and in fact is. The disruption to the ICE is already past the inflection point.
author: tropicalday88

text:
tropicalday88 For customers it does not matter if it is "I don't like alternative" or "I don't like current offering". Decision point is if it work or not. Currently EV cars are overpriced with poor mileage, questionable impact on environment and long charging time. I agree that this may work for some people but it will definitely not work for most of them.

You should also look at this from distance as on big picture. There are still lot of questions not answered about how things should work if everyone switch to EV car. For example what will be impact on "daily" and "trip" recharging (and others).

Right now it doesn't matter to much if you supercharge your car. There are not so much car in use so it will not make significant spike in power usage. With more and more EV cars and more users "daily" charging we sooner or later end-up with situation that charging car will require central management. Really the same situation as with big factories. This will lead to prolonged charging time which is already inconvenient for most of the people.

Similar situation will be with trip usage. Not all people have enough money to afford plane trip (or are willing, is available, etc.). It is not unusual to see queue on gas station during summer time. You will usually wait only couple of minutes if you end-up at gas station with queue. If this happen on EV charging spot then you may wait there for hours to get through queue ...

Another problem is that electricity is centrally operated. If gas station lose power then they start generator and continue to provide service. With electricity we still don't have efficient local storage so any blackout will cause major disruption. Search for example for "TV pickup" problem in United Kingdom. It will be exactly same with EV cars in future ...

Batteries are still not efficient enough. Therefore I think that EV cars are still dead end. Power train, inverters, UI and so on is great but we need another power source.  Something which is not loosing lot of power just by charging / discharging and can be "recharged" quickly. Something which can be stored locally and then quickly transferred to car. Really something similar to gas / diesel. I think that future is more like in fuelcells. You can generate "fuel" all day long and quickly transfer (pour) to car if required. This will allow quick "recharge". It will not cause too much stress on grid and you can generate "fuel" when there is excessive amount of energy (for example from solar panels during day). You can extend range by adding some containers in trunk and so on ...

... and my personal view at end. Some time ago I calculated what will be impact for me from switching from ICE to EV. I personally like "always connect" features of Tesla. Especially ability to preheat or cool car remotely but ... I drive a lot. I drive ~40 000km / yeay. Almost all my drives are ~ 500km and are on highway. With my current ICE car it is about 4 hour trip. Exactly same trip with Tesla is at least 5.5 hours and almost no range reserve at destination. This is still not counting waiting on charge spot and so on and it is huge impact. 

FYI: I know that my usage pattern far away from most of the people but it is one of the reason why we should not push this. Everyone should have opportunity to decide if EV car will work for him or not. I think there are still plenty of early adopters which are willing to sacrifice some of ICE benefits in order to have EV car ...
author: Lukas Dzunko

text:
PC's were expensive when they first hit the market. Now they are cheap. The first cars were expensive, then came the Model T. This was true for many of the modern conveniences you use today. Right down to your laptop PC, Smart Phone, and Tablet.
 
The current price of todays EV is mainly based on the cost of the battery cells. The initial cost was high. Demand grew faster than production. At the same time cost to produce LI-ON battery cells dropped as production efficiency increased. In order to address the demand companies are building massive manufacturing facilities. The chemistry of the LI-ON cell is also improving which increases energy density. The new 21700 cell (now being used in Tesla Model 3 and the new Power Wall/Pack) energy density is approximately a 35% increase. The cost to produce these cells is also dropping with scale. The new chemistry is fully recyclable. Your environmental argument is true with nickel-hydride and even that lead acid battery in your car today. This is not true for LI-ON.

Let me "big picture" this from what is happening. Even if everyone with a car wanted to drive an EV tomorrow in one large city the inventory world wide would be exhausted in less than a second. The demand today for EV's that people truly want already have to order them and wait. For some models only months, for others, they are looking at a year. Check out the road maps for the major manufactures and you can see that is not going to change in the near term. Demand is growing and manufactures targeting this demand will benefit. Others will pay a price.

With this increase in demand you are already seeing more and more charging stations. Many existing charging stations are already being upgraded as the technology improves with each passing year. This is a now thing, it is happening now. Does everyone go get gas at the same time today? No, they don't. Ever notice more than one fueling station at an intersection, or one just a block from another? Sometimes even the same brand? Solutions to this fear are already being addressed and will only improve. 

The majority of gas stations in the USA do not have backup generators. And we get all kinds of weather related disruptions. Hurricanes, floods, blizzards, ice storms, earth quakes, you name it. If you did not fill your tank before the event hit, if you are lucky enough to find a station with a generator you had better get their quick for his supply is limited and he will be out of fuel in no time. I have lived in both the north east and in the south east. I have lived through blizzards and hurricanes and been without power for days. No power, no fuel. As people flee the coast when majors summer storms hit they fill up and supply runs low. Having a generator does little good. 

Your fear of the grids impending catastrophic meltdown are greatly exaggerated. Utility operators know this is happening today. Have you not noticed utility scale solar farms in your travels? Wind turbines? You do realize the utilities are adding storage technologies to capture peak production from solar and wind for use later in the day or night. Did you know that some utilities in Europe enter into agreement with heavy industry with them so they will run an extra shift. They get the power for essentially nothing due to the excess power being generated from their base load plants? Have you notice the increase in rooftop solar? Did you know that Ikea now sells solar panels and battery storage as a packaged system? Ikea. That is a clear single that rooftop solar is now hitting mass market appeal. There is no going back.

 I like fuel cells and 10 years ago I thought they would develop quicker than battery technology. GM, Toyota, Mercedes, to name a few were throwing a ton of cash at their development with little to no investment in battery technology. The Toyota Pries with it's nickel-hydride battery did not even seem to excite Toyota. Then a few geeks in California built a little sports car based on the Lotus Eclipse using battery cells out of laptop PC's. That battery technology R&D's main drivers were your power hungry smart phones, tablets, and laptops. Kind of under the radar for automotive. One by one they have shifted their investments in fuel cells to EV's. Toyota is now shifting that investment to solid state batteries. That's still a lab project its promise is extended range and super fast charging. Could be five years out, could be ten. Economics will drive it's adoption. You will have to pay a premium for this convenience upon introduction. The challenge, LI-ON might be so cheap with more than enough energy density and fast enough charging to satisfy 80% of the market. That can really put a crimp in adoption due to cost differential. 

If you worry of the cost of EV's, then the cost of fuel cell power for cars should worry you much more. The the race to extend the range of EV's while dropping the cost of the battery packs and driving down charging times is already well underway. Fuel cells can not compete based on cost. Even large city busses are moving toward batteries not fuel cells for the same reason. They are some in London now. 

At 40,000KM a year you run about twice the US average which is about 12,000 miles. Our fuel has always been cheaper in the US due to generous subsidies to the oil and gas industry. I to was a high milage driver running over twice the US average (50,000KM) and never liked giving my money to the gas company. For every driver that runs twice the average there are two that have to run at half, or four at a quarter, or eight at.... Well you get the picture. That means for every driver like you there are at least twice as many that can easily switch to an EV without worry.

The cost of EV's will continue to drop. The selection will continue improve. Over time the EV not an ICE will be powering the automotive future. The economics of the EV is now in the driver seat. This change will accelerate. With renewable energy electricity will get cheaper, the fuel is free. Ikea is not selling you the future. They are selling to meet demand in a market that is already hitting main stream.

author: cachememory

text:
Personally, I'd start my research with projected resale value. I would avoid hybrids. The Honda Pries might be a great car and many love them. I would not buy one for two reasons. I believe they still use nickel-hydride batteries, and their is the added complexity of dual power plants. I Think Honda is the only one still using Nickel-hydride unless you are looking at golf carts. I believe the rest of the hybrids use LI-ON. Still, not on my list due to dual power plants. More to go wrong, more maintenance. At this point I would go with pure EV. That is just me. Many, many, people own hybrids and love them. If it works for you, it works for you. That's cool.

Now, here is where it is difficult for anyone not familiar with your specifics to make recommendations. I do not have any inside information in regards to manufactures specific plans for their battery pack capacities. It is safe to say that the race for range is now afoot in each segment. This trend will continue. The EV market is really just now starting to gain momentum. Some of the manufactures are in it now only for compliance purposes. That means low inventories and limited selection. Other have fully embraced the EV, they have sold well. That means low inventories and limited selection. Same problem for very different reasons. I'd want the full embrace. A compliance car is more likely to be a compromise of corporate priorities. 

For most price and range are key drivers for EV buyers. Not surprisingly the most affordable EV's have limited range. They work well for urban dwellers, people with short commutes, second car... This year some of these cars are due for a boost to get the low end to exceed 100 miles. Some are available with upgrades to larger battery packs.

The claim, for what it's worth, is the mass market acceptance for an EV means 200 mile range. Today there is the Chevy Bolt and the Tesla Model 3. I think the next Nissan Leaf will be close if not in there as well, could be a few more. The reality of taking delivery of a Model 3 within the next year is zero. Sold out long before release. The upside would be owning the latest technology with all the bugs worked out long before.

The rest of the EV market is the upscale luxury segment. Expensive but awesome. We can all dream.

So, this is really down to personal preference. I have never met an owner of a hybrid that was ambivalent or negative regarding their purchase. The same is true for EV owners. Of course they had the early adopter mentality. That phase has passed so it's up to you, your needs, and where you are with what you drive today (loan/lease dictates for most of us). I am well past the brand loyalty phase. If you like the car, it gets good reviews, and good resale value, then go for it. If range and selection are not meeting your criteria, then keep your powder dry until it does. It will. The prices will drop, and the selection will grow.
