author: DGFr0sty

text:
At this point in time electric cars are grabbing most of the press. Market opportunity has a lot to do with that. For example, the Royal Post is evaluating EV commercial vans for mail distribution and delivery. Cost of maintenance and fuel has all the big names in delivery DHL, UPS, and Fed-X looking to go electric.¬†
http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1112324_uk-royal-mail-electric-vans-now-entering-service

There are already EV buses on the road today built by BYD. There are both new companies entering this space as well as established companies like Blue Bird, the yellow school buss making "EV" announcements on a regular bases. And there is already movement in commercial trucking as well with announcements from Tesla, Nikola, Mercedes, Cummins, the list goes on.¬†

As for nautical applications, submarines when submerged run on battery power or nuclear power in military application. The vast majority of civilian application are battery powered. There has been a small number of electric powered boats for a long time. With advancements in battery technology some catamaran builders are now offering electric as main propulsion. True many will add a genset as a backup for solar and wind generation. Moonwave, a catamaran built by Gunboat is an awesome example.¬†http://www.moonwave.com
Moonwave is a high performance causing cat. There are many other more modest examples.¬†

As for synthetic my assumption is you are referring to biofuels. Brazil currently produces significant quantities from sugar cane waste which is great. They also produce a lot of oil. Biofuel is cleaner. It cost more and is not as energy dense giving gas a mileage advantage. Brazil also enjoys an abundance of solar and wind. 

While biofuels might be fine to bridge a gap and a good application might be large ships that are hybrids running diesel electric and some military applications. Fuel cell technology might play a role as well. As for most passenger cars, buses, and trucks, the EV march is already well underway.¬†

The future is closer than you think. Everyone will not be driving an EV tomorrow. Tomorrow more people will be driving EV's. And in greater numbers.

text:
You need to go back and read the rules, laws, and regulations for a drivers license. Then take a look at what is required for a CDL. Sure you can drive like an a-hole, try telling that to the cop after he pulls you over. That free will you speak of does not exist on public roads. It does not even exist on race tracks. As anyone who has had the misfortune of dealing with the DMV will tell you, your drivers license is a privilege not a right. Don't believe me, try to argue this in court. Nothing to do with an ICE versus an EV, nothing.

As for babbling. Your arguments for one technology over another are baseless, all feelings, no facts. And yes, the ICE is a technology, just a very old one. The cost to produce one versus the other? Maintenance cost? Service life? Replacement cost?¬†

How efficient is the average ICE compared to an electric motor? A really good design averaged out across 4 cylinder to V8's around 20%. The electric motor in EV's are over 93%. Everything blowing out that exhaust system is waste. In Brazil they make biofuel on the cheap and flex fuel cars are common. Still, it's typically more expensive than gas and lacks the range. So even when it cost the same per liter, people still buy gas because its cheaper per mile. It's cost that drives their behavior. Just where are they producing biofuel so cheaply people are driving out of their way to fill up on? It cost less to recharge an EV at home than the cost of one gallon of gas.¬†

Cost will drive the move to EV's. Make an effort to debate on the merits of one technology over another instead of how you feel about Hollywood, billionaires, NASA (unless they have worked on a new ICE), or some other climate conspiracy ¬†theory. How you feel about that social order has nothing to do with cost or efficiencies of one technology over the other. Once you drive an EV maybe you will change your mind, maybe you won't. That will have zero impact on the cost equation. And that is all the manufacturers are concerned with. Not one of the incumbent manufactures want to change. They had rather milk what they got forever if they could. They change because they know EV's are cheaper to operate and have better cost of ownership numbers. They are moving to EV's to stay in business.
¬†
One thing you are right about. Cars are now computers on wheels. The rate of this innovation will only increase. Autonomous automobiles are already on the road so that horse is already out of the barn. And some are powered by ICE. It's already a billion dollar industry that every major auto manufacturer is buying or jumping in to bed with including the ones you have such a romantic attachment to. 
¬†I'm in my late 50's, and worked on the computer technology you are using to post your rants, before there were PC's or the internet. I have first hand experience working and watching ¬†technology change just about everything. I can't help the fact that those smarty pants kids on youtube or other social media sites get your boxers in a bunch. Try to bear in mind that this YouTube video trying to stoke the flames of your love for the ICE was developed by, and the servers supported by, those young whippersnappers.

text: +Bayan Zabihiyan just a few notes to your comment. The worlds hydrogen production comes mainly from Gas, oil and coal  without  electricity in between.  The process to obtain H2 from these resources creates large quantities of CO2 as a byproduct  .  Electrolysis of Water to obtain Hydrogen is only something like 4% of the worlds production due to the inefficiency and high cost of that process. Also it's not stored in liquid form but in highly compressed gas form (10000psi for FCV use) because it has a higher energy density and is easier to store that way.

text: The energy density of hydrogen is absolutely pathetic - fuel cell or not. (unless you're operating at absolute zero).  Li Ion is a stepping stone (and orders of magnitude more energy dense) and I believe, will be replaced with advanced carbon based meta-materials. Hydrogen generation still uses fossil fuels for electrolysis, hard to store, extremely low energy density - requiring bulky compressed cylinders (and the power to compress it!), ridiculously dangerous - it's a dead horse. Let it die.

text:
≈Ωan Fingu≈°t Yes, they use the same battery technology as smartphones. No, this doesn't mean they'll degrade as fast as smartphones. Batteries in EVs are heavily cooled to maintain a proper temperature without degrading them too much. It's also much easier to stay out of the battery reserve (80%+ and 10%-) with cars than it is with smartphones. 

Batteries are likely one of the very last things you'll ever need to replace. That is, if the rest of the car lasts as long. Plus, battery cell prices are decreasing at such a fast pace that it may not be so expensive in the rare case that you do need to replace them.

Diego Garcia Not sure if you're being sarcastic or not...

A tiny percentage of lithium ion batteries is actually lithium. Lithium isn't even as rare as people think. 

Yes, batteries degrade with time but, unless you're talking about a Nissan Leaf, it won't be significant enough to actually warrant a battery replacement during the car's lifetime. 

The Chevy Bolt and Tesla Model 3 have 220+ miles of range. Other Tesla motors can go above 330+. In city driving, that range is even longer.

Charging time is actually an advantage of EVs. It only takes less than 5 seconds to plug in when you get home vs the time it takes you to drive to a gas station, wait to fill up, then drive away in a gas car.

text:
When you get to the point of replacing your ICE car, then you may wish to get an EV. For now, however, due to the lack of infrastructure in many areas, this may not be the appropriate choice (for daily driving to/from work & shopping errands w/a home charger - EV makes more sense).  
Old cars are still recycled as they've been for decades for the metals, rubber & plastic bits. 
Old EVs would be recycled as well (especially for the Aluminum - since recycling Al takes less energy than producing it from bauxite ore) - the battery included, for Lithium recovery (since Li is both rare & expensive - conserving it is a must)
Because EV batteries are still friggin' heavy, the body components have to be made of lightweight materials to compensate. Electrifying a typical steel framed/paneled car would not be very efficient.
There is still the issue with charging time, of course, and theoretically (and from an electrical engineer's perspective), I can't see that improving much (like someone here mentioned, to dump in 250-300 MegaJoules worth of power into a battery in <5 minutes would not be feasible) beyond 20 minutes for a full charge for safety reasons, rapid heating of the battery system & the wear on the cells & interconnects, not to mention the on-demand power load from the power company.

text:
WHO, are you in for a shock. Teslas are serviced on a 4-year rotating plan. If you want to keep your warranty, you will pay them what they charge. https://www.tesla.com/Support/maintenance-plans-ms-mx

In years 1 and 3 (12,500 and 37,500 miles) it's not all that ugly: they replace your key fob battery and wiper blades, rotate the tires, do a four-wheel alignment and a multi-point inspection.  This costs $475.

At 25,000 miles you also get an air conditioner desiccant bag replacement, brake fluid replacement and cabin air filter replacement. This service is $725.

At 50,000 miles, the $850 service is the same as the 25,000-mile service with the addition of a battery coolant replacement.

If you pay up front, the service is $2325 for all four years.

In reality, most people will trade the car in when it needs that 50,000-mile service, so the dealer will just subtract the $850 from the trade-in value.

On the other hand, if you buy a BMW that is the same size as a Tesla Model S (530e plug-in hybrid), it's half the price and they change the oil, oil filter, brake fluid, cabin and engine air filters, spark plugs and key fob batteries for free for the three years you'll have it before you trade it in.

author: DevasionX

text:
Your facts are completely off.
Most lithium mined (about 99%) is used for microelectronic batteries for phones and laptops, not cars, currently (it is infinitely and easily recyclable as well). Neodymium is not used in inductive motors at all, nor is selenium (maybe in some electrical circuit components - namely LEDs). You may find neodymium in some DC motors/generators where weight or compactness is concerned (portable drills, tiny servos & motors). Hydrogen gas is generated today almost exclusively via petro fuels, and petro fuels are used to create your so-called synthetic fuel (growing fuel is an ecological disaster & wastes a tremendous amount of petro-fuels w/ a net power return worse than solar - really) and already not a viable solution. Most ICEs today are made of Aluminum, not iron.  If you count all sources of energy (conventional & alternative excluding nuclear), we have plenty to power 1.5billion vehicles - especially since EVs are 10X more efficient overall (even if they use petro fuels to generate the power) - this IS looking at the entire picture (which things like drilling, cracking, scrubbing,inserting additives to,transporting, pipelining, & pumping of petrol is completely ignored by the oil magnates - not to mention a myriad of auxiliary operations in the support of petrol - nary we say include off-gassing ).  
The only truth said here is concerning the relative abundance and output of lithium (not enough) - fortunately, there are other alternatives already in the works to reduce lithium to a fraction of what is needed via better electrode materials.  I feel, however, that Lithium should only be used where weight is of concern and should not be used in PowerWalls or any onsite power generation.

text: Love how they only compare electric to gas, not diesel, which requires a ton less "complicated" exhaust mechanism, aka straight out the turbo no catalytic converter needed.
author: Nathan Schlenker

text: I'm not sure where you got that from, diesels require ridiculously complex exhaust after-treatment. Diesels need a particulate filter (DPF), an oxidation catalyst (DOC) and a urea injection system (NOx traps don't actually work), which is a system that requires you to keep a urea (which is made from cow piss) tank full. The urea injection system has it's own electronic injection system which injects urea into the exhaust and then another catalytic converter is used to react the urea with the exhaust to reduce NOx emissions. All of this after treatment is so restrictive that it reduces the efficiency of diesels enough to where they don't have lower CO2 emissions when compared to gasoline engines, it's also expensive and is a source of constant problems for modern diesel engines. The diesels that don't have all of this equipment produce massive amounts of pollution.
author: TheBrokenWorld

text: TheBrokenWorld That must be area specific. I know where I live, in Pennsylvania, there are no emissions requirements on diesel, and you literally run the exhaust straight off the turbo.
author: Nathan Schlenker

text: A gasoline engine also doesn't require a complicated exhaust mechanism  to run but to make the exhaust cleaner.  By now the Diesel engine,  which a few years back was advertised as the cleaner/better ICE ,  has moved under the negative spot light for pollution and is seen a root cause for respiratory diseases and as +TheBrokeWorld mentioned now require elaborate exhaust emission control systems in some places of this world and diesel vehicles may even be prohibited to be driven in some larger cities/areas unless they meet latest exhaust emission control standard (thank to Dieselgate to an accelerated push on this)
author: Milan Swoboda

text: Whether or not you're required to have those controls depends on the area where you live, but you can't buy a new diesel without those emissions control systems. text: The voiceover is wrong - EVs cost 1/3 per mile to operate, not 1/3 less. You also overstated the cooling issues with an EV - an ICE creates an order of magnitude more waste heat than an EV does. In fact, even at idle, if the ICE's cooling system fails the engine seizes. An EV needs no such cooling system and several EVs today are air cooled (Nissan Leaf). You also forgot to mention the safety issues that accompany an ICE - you're carrying around liquid explosive! Also mention that 75% of gasoline burning is wasted in heat whereas an EV is 90% efficient.

text:
The point made at 3:07 makes no sense at all and is wrong on so many levels. First we are interested in traction not friction which are two different things.Second the coefficient of friction between tow materials is constant (if the temperature is constant), it's is a dimensionless scalar value which describes the ratio of the force of friction between two bodies and the force pressing them together (the load). which brings me to my third point, greater load makes for better traction which makes for better stability.  
And I can't find that graph anywhere and it's nonlinear, so ... go figure.

author: FifthTechnik

text: Hydrogen cars are hybrid cars so basically electric cars with a smaller capacity  battery pack that have a hydrogen fuel cell system added to generate electricity for the e-drive system.  These hydrogen fuel cells add complexity, maintenance and cost to the simpler all electric car thus is a hard sell with EV battery prices continually falling. Furthermore Hydrogen is costly to produce, with the most cost effective Hydrogen production method being reformation of natural gas by the petrol industries which creates lots of  CO2 as a byproduct,  which makes it even harder to sell. Production of hydrogen via water electrolysis is highly inefficient so you use far more electricity to create hydrogen then you would use for charging a battery only EV.  Possibly in the future science will find/develop a bacteria that will generate sufficient low cost Hydrogen out of the Garbage human kind leaves behind but until then I think the battery based EV has a bigger chance of competing against the ICE Vehicle at this time.

author: David Lazarus

text:
@ 1905934: While it is true that electric motors can operate effectively over a wide range of speeds, and therefore a multi-speed transmission isn't necessary, it is incorrect to say that they have no need for any gear reduction at all. 

To achieve a desirable rate of acceleration without any gear reduction would require an unnecessarily large, heavy motor, while at the same time giving you an unnecessarily high mechanical top speed as well.  Even your own numbers (after correcting for your mathematical error) (assuming your stated tire diameter is correct) would give a mechanical theoretical top speed of about 937 miles per hour.

So no, "direct drive" without any gear reduction is not how it works in the vast majority of cases, including vehicles.  (Small home appliances like blenders and fans may be different, but we're talking about cars here.)   The Tesla Model S, for example, has a single-speed gearbox with a 9.73-to-1 gear ratio.

text:
While Electric motors are simpler and more reliable mechanical wise, it requires a lot of expensive electronics around it. Power regulator, AC/DC converter, charger, a bunch of safety circuits for the battery, and so on. The electronics won't last as long as the mechanical, even though in a Tesla the mechanical isn't reliable either.
But I guess electric is the future, but it won't be with a battery, because we produce too little electricity around the world. 
We need a fuel type that can be transported around and refueled in a short time, therefore Hydrogen is the only real alternative to fossil fuels. 
Diesel is hard to beat when it comes to energy density. I drove 5000 km around europe with a 2005 mercedes e class that has done 370.000km. Just a simple trip on autobahn of 900 km in 6 hours would have been a problem with an electric car. Even at high speeds the consumption never went higher than 8l/100km.

The ideal Otto cycle for Spark ignition engines (petrol engines) and The ideal diesel cycle for well... diesel engines... because of the difference in material used, stages in work output generation and self-ignition temperature of type of fuel, petrol engines, on average lose by cold air standard assumptions, 70% of what is actually used... however in diesel engines an average of 45% efficiency is achieved by cold air standard assumptions... NB the maths suggests that if a more durable material is  used and an increase in compression ratios improve to about 14, efficiencies would be around 70%  and more... at the moment race cars have an efficiency of 50%.

author: seeburgm100a

text:
"That electric power you use to recharge your car is generated mostly using fossil fuels"
That's not accurate everwhere or at all times of the day. For example in Norway 100% of domestic electricity is from renewables and in Costa Rica it's 98.1%. In my home country of Ireland over 50% (some days of the year up to 85%) of electricity at the times most cars are charging (between midnight and 9AM.. when we get a preferential rate) is generated by renewables.

"IF we went to all electric cars we would need MORE energy generated"
That's true to a point. Although in many countries up to half of road mileage could be transferred to electric WITHOUT increasing generation, merely by charging cars during periods of lower grid demand. Until grid demand across 24 hours is a fairly balanced and you are increasing the peak energy demanded on the grid you don't need to build more power generation (although works to the low voltage grid would be required as residential grids would need to be reinforced with that number of cars charging). You also have the effect of using wasted energy and production capacity for plants that are currently kept idling (like combined cycle gas plants) because they can't easily be throttled up and down and take days or week to restart if shutdown.

"the amount of fossil fuels used to create that electric energy would be nearly the same."
Now that's total nonsense. Because of the greater efficiency including losses of the EVs the total energy consumption to move the same cars, passengers and cargo the same distance and at the same speed is between 2 and four times lower.... that's including all generation, storage and distribution losses.

text:
electric car is nowhere near 90% efficient, you cant look at it as just an engine, but rather a chain. First, you need to create the electric power. The more dependent your wallplug is from fossil fuel, the more wasted energy (and emissions) generally. Your wallplug can depend close to 90% from coal plants and close to 100% from renewable/nuclear sources, coal plants having only 33% efficiency. There are losses with renewables of course but these do not waste types of energy we are short on. Second, you need to transfer this energy from power plant to your wallplug, which introduces 8-13% loss. Third, there is a loss when charging the battery pack and again(fourth) loss during discharge. Both of these vary from 3-sh to whopping 30% depending on current and voltage. And only then you reach the electric engines impressive 90% efficiency, another 10% loss.
Note that steps 1-4 have no losses for internal combustion engine

author: Martin Balber

text:
@Martin Balber Got a source for any of that? Every... and I mean EVERY industry source puts TOTAL transmission losses (so that includes both transmission and local distribution) at 3-10% depending on the grid (our smart grid in Ireland is both one of the most advanced in the world and physically compact... so we're on the lower end). We've drastically increased the quantity of renewables on our grid in the last 20 years, while demand increased and many combustion fuel plants have closed. It's also really easy to see because we publish live data: http://smartgriddashboard.eirgrid.com/#all/generation?scroll=fuel
Average renewable generation last year was about 44% of the total, and hit near 90% of demand several times last year. This year we closed our second last coal plant, with the last closing before 2024. We have very little solar on the grid yet, but there are connection applications from developers for solar PV equivalent to our entire generating capacity. The plan is to move to 80%+ renewable generation on an annual basis by the 2025-2030 period.
Also where did you hear that "Renewable is not reliable. Period.". We have prognostic generation forecasts based on these new-fangled things called 7-day weather forecasts that allow us to predict wind generation ahead of time and a real time open market that prices generation accordingly... it's accurate enough, take a look at the monthly data: http://smartgriddashboard.eirgrid.com/#all/wind
Also... we have storage... both in the form of pumped water storage (several additional plants under construction including one in an old silver mine in the mountains above my place in the country) and batteries (200MW battery also being built pretty near me)

text:
@Martin Balber Yes, they're lying. I know the full background to Australia's issues (I don't have time to watch these particular videos but I assume they are as accurate as ABC's previous coverage... not very accurate). I would point out that Australia's grid is mostly coal ( https://www.aer.gov.au/wholesale-markets/wholesale-statistics/generation-capacity-and-output-by-fuel-source ), they have minimal renewable generation capacity on their grid comparative to most 1st world countries. That particular grid is operated by Transgrid and after a somewhat botched privatization in the 90s has had little investment, it's quite old and fragile with poor interconnection.
The total bollocks their energy ministry has been putting out absent any supporting evidence had more to do with a plan by one of their local political parties to build a new generation of coal plants, even when contradicting reports from AEMO on the actual events didn't support their conclusions they still pushed the lie that renewable generation had something to do with the blackout.
You will note that economic realities have prevented the australians from getting funding for those new coal plants... nobody in the private sector was willing to put money into them, and even with substantial barriers to entry such as grid connection issues (like I said, crap grid, little investment) private, subsidy free solar and wind (and some battery storage) is filling nearly all of their new supply coming on line.... even as older coal plants are retired.
I would also point out that despite a massive potential for developing renewables, the barriers put in place by the australians to subsidize their coal industry have meant that australians pay some of the highest electricity prices in the world.
Oh... and if you don't believe me on transmission losses... here's your own EIA: https://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.php?id=105&t=3
And here's EIA average data by US state: http://insideenergy.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/State_Losses.png

author: 0hypnotoad0

text: @0hypnotoad0 the total efficiency losses for electric cars need to start from the fuel that is used to generate power . The total losses are the summation of the losses in the power generator, the transformer, the charger and at last the electric car motor and invertor that transfer power from DC to AC. So if consider the efficiency of the diesel generator is 70 percent, the transformer 90 percent, the charger 90 percent, the inverter inside the car 90 percent and the Induction motor 85 percent. The fuel cars would end up much more efficient.

text: You could artificially add vibration and sound without much hassle. It wouldn't be "natural", which probably matters at least for nostalgic reasons. You will also be able to work on EVs, but it will be more software and high voltage oriented. You could also put a "beautiful V8 engine" in the EV, without using it - there's plenty of space. I think even 20-30 years is a very aggressive target, since global vehicle production is only ~1/20 of the global fleet. So if 100% of all vehicles produced today were electric, it would still take 20 years for the fleet to become electric. And we're not nearly there yet - so more realistic is probably minimum 40 years. And there'll always be a niche around for old stuff - just like there's veteran cars and people riding horses.

author: .:Camper:.

text:
@.:Camper:. Then ur 'energy density' is determined by some other stuff like current collector, electrolyte, separator, cell casing etc. It will be different for different batteries .Different batteries have different weights and total energy that can be provided before running out. Even the fuel cell array  is still a battery, using oxidising reactions to pump electrons, but instead of the fuel being installed during manufacture it is fed to the battery as it is used.  This allows the fuel to be stored separately and supplied to the cell as required, and the oxidising agent is just oxygen itself and so doesn‚Äôt need to be stored at all. This allows the 'energy density' to approach that of the gasoline.
So how is it still  0.36MJ/kg ?

text:
@.:Camper:. lol üòÇyou seems to be pissed off by the new electric cars. Alright now note this. The most advanced combustion engine developed so far has near 50% efficiency only .And that is only when a supercharger is used.
Where as efficiency of an electric motor using battery can reach near 95% without using any suppliments.

The definition of battery is combination of cells which can convert chemical energy into electrical energy. So fuel cell array is a battery. As far as vehicles are concerned, powering an electric vehicle by this battery is around four times as efficient as by combustion engine. So even though ethanol has half the energy density of petrol, your ethanol fuel cell array battery electric vehicle will have around twice the range of your petrol car for the same fuel tank capacity, and refuel at the same rate as your petrol car. Meanwhile the ethanol will be manufactured from electricity generated from power plants including renewable sources.

I respect your suggestion to use hydrogen as fuel as it is non polluting .As you may know it has more than 3 times the energy density of gasoline. But that's energy per unit mass. But how much kg of hydrogen can you store in your fuel tank?It has very low density at atmospheric pressure. The only solution here is to liquify hydrogen .It requires 5000-10000 psi tank pressure and cryogenic temperatures. Are you gonna get that in an IC engine.?

Another problem is hydrogen molecules are extremely small. So even if hydrogen is inside a tight container ,its diffusion through the walls is insidious . So unfortunately we can't use it here.

author: Mikko Haavisto

text:
Many counter arguments I received are very simplistic. Here are some reasons:
1. If you want to be environment friendly, drive and repair your old car for as long as possible. Half of the emissions of a car come from manufacturing it. A new electric car is a big hit on the environment.
2. Government doesn't subsidize the production of gas cars in the same way it does electric cars. The fact that all different energy sources are subsidized is irrelevant to this point.
3. There is nowhere near the production nor the environment to be sacrificed for production to move from gas cars to electric cars anytime soon. If all people suddenly wanted to change to an electric car, it would be a huge environmental catastrophe.
4. If you switch to using 96 % renewables, that means that coal and gas power price drops, which makes someone else change from renewable to coal and gas. Supply and demand. The real way to improve is that everyone would care about environment (most don't) or some sort of regulation.

text:
1. It's not like cars are being thrown away after the first owners use them for a few years, cars will often be on the road for 20-25 years before they're scrapped, and that's pretty much the limit of their life. If the people who buy new cars don't sell them after using them for a time, the people who can only afford to buy used cars will end up having to drive cars that are absolutely falling apart after being driven for 30+ years and hundreds of thousands of miles. 

2. The government subsidizes the fuel you burn in ICE vehicles. Americans also subsidize fossil fuels with their lives and with multi-trillion dollar military campaigns in the middle east, that's unacceptable.

3. That's nothing but fossil fuel industry propaganda. Producing batteries isn't even remotely close to being as environmentally harmful as the extraction, transportation and refining of fossil fuels.

4. The price of fossil fuels will only continue to increase as they become more difficult to extract. Demand for fossil fuels will drop to a point where the fossil fuel industry can no longer cover their overhead costs, so they'll have to raise the price of their products until they're no longer competitive, and they're already not competitive with electric cars. This is how new technologies have replaced old technologies all throughout history. 

You can't care about the environment by using technologies that are inherently harmful to it.

text: +Murray Kitson ,  that carbon technology is being used to increase the specific energy in rechargeable batteries as well so I wouldn't get my hopes up on them ever surpassing.  The exponential discharge curve of batteries make them a better choice for an EV where you need a constant (high) voltage over an extended period of time which the linear discharge characteristics of a capacitor does not provide. However capacitors can be charged and discharged very rapidly without ill effect so they might come into play for smoothing out large charge and discharge spikes like +Dude31463 mentioned above. So IMO batteries and capacitors (super, ultra,...)  will coexist down the road but one won't replace the other.

text: true that. Infrastructure is lacking, but it's cheaper to run & maintain electric power cabling (including HV towers) than to run & maintain piping, pumps, trains, trucks, and ships need to transport fuel (not including the cost of cleanup due to spills, leaks, traffic accidents). So the "expense" argument is ultimately moot (there, will be a start up expense, just as there was when ICE vehicles were making their appearance). ICE vehicles lose ~95% of the energy of the fuel used to power them - for every liter of petrol, you waste 950mL (if that wasn't the case, you could travel 8000miles on a tank of gas). Even if you powered the EVs solely from fossil fuels, presuming the infrastructure was there, they would still win via efficiency alone (even considering transmission line losses, conversion losses, storage losses @20-25%). It will only get better as battery power density improves.

author: Joseph Brody

text:
+Repurplecirculation They are cheaper than pipelines sure in part because the land easements for towers are way cheaper than the land take of a pipeline, prices start in the region of around $180k/km though that is for like a small 70kV or so line over relatively flat open rural terrain higher capacities urban environments with high land value and high lobbying costs fighting the local NIMBY's or terrain complications (Mountains, bodies of water etc that must be traversed) will increase costs. That's for overhead lines too underground the cost goes up to closer to $1M/km as the civil works get expensive. Course this is based on fairly old data I was given when we last had to deal with the issue of getting a bulk transmission line installed for a high consumption business premises. Fossil fuel pipelines on the other hand yeah those start at a few million dollars per km if google searches are anything close to reliable there no personal experience with them so can't say with any certainty if it's accurate or internet BS.

Changing the frequency of the entire grid and upgrading it to 6 phase though in it's entirety that is serious capital, the 6 phase supply is probably easier to do in phases though I imagine as you can I imagine easily split a 6 phase line into two 3 phase lines at the edge of an upgraded area of the grid. Changing the frequency is really much more complex you can't mix frequencies on the same AC grid period you need to do something like AC-DC-AC conversion to link them so phasing it in would be like building out an entire parallel grid at first most likely from what I understand about electrical transmission that is I am not an electrical engineer though I only really know what I've read and learned from people way smarter on the topic than I am.

Doable though I am sure phased upgrades are hardly anything new for any infrastructure network and especially not the energy supply networks, it's kinda the standard modus operandi of operating energy supply infrastructure for a civilisation that constantly demands ever more energy both per capita and for the ever increasing population on top.

text:
+A random swede plays Honestly in my opinion it sounds like your arguments are mostly based in the nostalgia of the car please don't misunderstand me on this I actually kinda agree it's a part of our history and would be a shame to lose it completely. That said I guess I agree more in the sense I certainly would hate to see heritage railways running the preserved steam locomotives that represent not only a vital step in the development of the railway but a vital part of the dawn of the industrial age, on the other hand that also doesn't mean I feel like we should have rejected diesel and electric locomotive and should use only steam locomotives today.

Also I do hear what you are saying about renewable fuels like ethanol but sadly I am fully aware that it's not an option to keep all vehicles running the truth is that we really don't have sufficient agricultural resources to grow both 100% biofuels for transport at anything like current levels AND produce enough food for the current 7.5 billion people let alone the 9 projected for 2050 or the anticipated plateu in population at ~10.5-11 billion. Worse if we could get serious vertical farming working economically to cover that the global population can be expected to explode once again (Every major breakthrough in agriculture before which has boosted the food supply has done this).

The truth is that we have a number of tricky problems ahead of us and while everyone constantly focuses on climate change and I certainly do see it's a major problem and one we need to deal with I'm not blind to the fact that we have a number of other issues, fresh water availability is being stretched globally, pushing our agricultural land as hard is also a big concern not only is it being depleted to the point of being useless in some regions of the world but at current rates we are going to struggle to mine enough phosphorus for fertiliser in around 2050 now granted that is likely to go the way of peak oil with ever increasing prices for food as fertiliser gets more expensive as opposed to some of the more paranoid projections but it's certainly something to give some consideration to.

Honestly I really do get the feeling that we really are getting to the point where it's time to start really accepting the reality we can't just keep trying to boost both the global population and living standards the way we are and expect to do it all on this one single planet alone. That said I think this is starting to sink in with both governments and private sectors more and more, at least I hope so and that this time the apparently renewed space race we have going on doesn't end up being another ridiculously wasteful exercise in showing off and that we actually do start establishing real colonies and economic activity in space this time around. Sure that wont fix climate change but if we can fix that hurdle and in the process survive to becoming a space faring race over the next say 50-80 years I think it will be a real turning point.

And yes I know that some are aiming to set a colony on mars before 50 years from now but I am talking more 50-80 years to make it not an exercise in showing off and actually start proving economic value to the project by actually developing a proper space based economy, until that happens we really are never going to properly establish our species as an interplanetary species because well if it's not producing a return on investment why would people really allocate the significant time and effort that would be needed to step it up to the next level it's not going to happen even if the economy is post-scarcity after all time and effort are currency too!

text: You have to have both. The capacitors charge on braking and release the energy in a burst for the start. Once the car is up to speed you need the battery to take over because it holds the long charge. The addition of capacitors greatly increases battery life because the heavy battery draw on power from a start is decreased (smooths out the power spikes). A capacitor can also discharge a larger wattage at one time.

text: DrToonhattan---   Yeah, and those warranties are prorated, that is, the older they get the less warranty support they get and thus the larger portion of its' replacement cost you'll have to pay.  The question of the replacement cost is still valid.  Furthermore, the more energy dense the batteries have become the less stable they've become, as well.  Battery fires are a common occurrance and are becomming increasingly so as battery technology advances.  Finally, the electric motors themselves are a problem as to mass density and thus weight.  Not only are baterries heavy as hell but so, too, are the motors, and as we all learned in grade school (didn't we?) the greater the mass & weight, the greater must be the applied torque to overcome inertia.  In plain 'car-speak', the more horsepower is consumed when you accelerate from a stop.  Not very efficient.  You will notice that in all of these e-car presentations not once do they mention vehicle weight.  Heavier vehicles are not only less efficient, but also respond with less agility to turn inputs and braking inputs.  Slow-stopping, shitty handling, and energy-gobbling acceleration, and this is 'the wave of the future'?  No, thanks.

brian whittle you know, not everything is a giant conspiracy. Maybe it's just not economically viable to create an electric car. Think about it.

Well for starters batteries were really expensive, and still are relatively expensive. At $250/kWh you need to spend $15,000 for just the battery alone. Even at the industry "goal" of $100/kWh it's still expensive to manufacture electric cars.

text:
Dude31463 That only works with acceleration. And even then it doesn't really improve your 0-100 times, it just reduces wheelspin when you start going from the standstill, which results in lesser chance of getting stuck. But you can achieve that through other means than increasing your weight. Increasing weight should be your last ditch effort in order to get going under slippery conditions, if all else fails.
For engineers best ways to increase traction are better tires, better weight distribution and better handling of weight transfer. They NEVER would just increase weight to improve traction
author: SingleTurboSupra

text: SingleTurboSupra ... I understand your point... Weight or Mass is not the only way for better traction & stability... Race cars use Aerodynamic Down-force to achieve this also in addition to , of course, tire compounds, contact patch area, suspension geometry, traction control systems, etc... The electric car also offers much better Aerodynamic sculpting, not only for more down-force, but also less drag. Case in point NIO EP9 recently set a lap record @ the Nurburgring. Beautiful car too.:)
author: Dude31463

text:
Yes, there sure is dozens of  things that are important as well in designing cars than weight. 
But I just want to point out that when designing whatever kind of vehicle, be it racecar, a street car, a bike or even a heavy duty truck, the engineers NEVER purposefully make the vehicle heavier than it needs to be. There's lot more disadvantages than advantages by having more weight on a vehicle. Bigger weight isn't desirable! Although some vehicles are heavier by default the engineers still try to make them as light as possible for the task they are needed. Electric car is indeed heavier than ICE-car, but the engineers task is to still make it as light as possible and also try to handle the extra weight as good as possible (placing the weight low, and designing suspension so that there's no excessive weight transfer etc.)

author: Elias Castillo

text: The coefficient of friction or "tire load sensitivity" mentioned in the video is really a non-issue. ¬†Take the Tesla Model S for example. ¬†There are other cars in its class that are only ~100 lighter than the biggest battery and power P100D. ¬†The "tire load sensitivity" is also a very weak effect. When on the road, people are not constantly driving the limit of the tire traction so any difference would go unnoticed. ¬†The Model S has a very low center of gravity, which counter acts issues with tire load sensitivity because load transfer is not a dramatic as a car with a higher center of gravity. ¬†The particular tires are going to be a big factor though.

4) Test drove a Tesla Model S: Heavyweight + Electric + LOW wheel base. GREAT CORNERING! CS = 4.5

My Conclusion: LOW Wheel Base Height + GOOD Tire Tread + HIGH ROAD Friction + HIGH SKILL of Driver = GREAT CORNERING! : )

author: Bryan Hensley

text:
I'm well aware of thermodynamics. 

Thermodynamics has little to do with material balance. Thermodynamics is a measure of energy efficiency (what is the maximum theoretical conversion of energy of type A to energy of type B? what did we actually get? and what can we do to get better?). I'm guessing because you are a thermodynamics chemist, you are more concerned with the the change of enthalpy of reaction (hess's law) and rates of reaction (kinematics). Maybe you design catalysts, to reduce activation energy of reaction. These ideas are a small subset of thermodynamics in general.

Maybe this is why you think lithium is 100 percent recoverable. It's not.

Tell me, in any of your chemistry labs, when you did an extraction, did you ever achieve a 100 percent yield? 

No you didn't.

Some methods are good at physically separating chemicals, such as distillation. But even distillation can come into problems. Such as the chemicals behaving as azeotropes. Even if you're separating two very different species, that easily come apart, you still won't have 100 percent recovery, because no industrial process is truly closed. Actually, there are textbooks written on this stuff, to make better designs with higher yields.

To say you can get 100 percent of anything recycled to the point where you don't need to mine for new material, well you might as well claim that free energy and perpetual motion are possible (they're not).

The real world is never 100 percent efficient, not from the stand point of thermodynamics, not from the stand point of material balance.
author: Jon L

text:
Bryan Hensley no one on Earth is making the claim that there will be no gas cars by 2037 (well except you).

Even if 100 percent of cars sold suddenly switched too all electric it would still take decades to replace the billion ICE cars on the roads today. 

It would take over 55 years for the entire world fleet of vehicles to become electric. This is because the world outputs only about 17.5 million new cars per year.

1 billion cars in world fleet / 17.5 million new cars made per year = more than 55 years to replace world fleet of vehicles with EVs.

text:
Bryan Hensley by 2040 the majority of electricity being generated will be generated by burning natural gas. Therefore electric vehicles will be basically natural gas cars.

Look up the EIA energy forecasts for 2040. Renewables will increase but so to does natural gas. By 2040 there will be two types of cars on the road, gasoline cars, and natural gas cars (EVs). Gasoline usage is not forecast to decrease or increase, but natural gas usage is forecast to dramatically increase.

People have developed genetically modified cork trees that absorb large amounts of CO2 from the atmosphere. I read that if 5 percent of crop land is replaced by these trees it would absorb all CO2 produced by ICE vehicles. But why replace crop land? just replant forests with genetically modified trees that absorb a lot more CO2. If the trees absorb too much CO2, cut them down, and burn them or use them as wood.

I think this geo engineering approach is a lot more interesting than EVs because you can apply geo engineering to other planets, and it would be useful to develop this technology for space exploration.
author: Jon L

text: Jon L I personally don't believe in global warming doomsday forecasts. You are right about the C02. Earth can take care of herself better than we give credit. You can ask anyone who's into green houses that C02 can almost double if not double the growth. Earth will get more green as C02 levels rise which absorb more C02. In fact some studies of the previous weather on Earth when the ice caps were melted show almost no deserts on Earth. These deserts would contain a majority of the extra water. In fact the ice caps could be the main cause of the dead lands by starving the Eco system of water in those areas.
author: Bryan Hensley

text: Jon L I agree with you on alot of stuff. I think copper will be the first thing that dwindles in supply. There is no agressive recycling program in place and it's easily recycled. Supply vs demand, who knows. More jobs to replace the lost ones maybe. They are too close to finding the perfect material and/or chemical combination for batteries for it not to be a huge break though coming soon. It may have already happened. Just like Edison tried over 5000 different materials to get the light bulb to be usable. Someone will figure out the combination for a 50 year plus battery and most likely more energy dense. By the way, my thermodynamics experience is useful in building this invention that uses chemical reaction through heat transfer to create motion in which creates electric power. We are currently building a prototype now. Right now it will only work in a certain window of temperature. For example 0 degrees F to 120 degrees F. (Considerably less output at 0 too). But we  don't really care about that now, we just want to get it to work. Like I said, it absorbs heat from the air at anything above 0 degrees F and turns it into motion which will run a generator. I give it a 90% chance of working, but who knows, Murphy's law hovers around. Then you'll actually use Earth's heat to charge your cars and homes. It can run 24/7 if necessary. We are focusing on a 7.5 kwh output capacity for the prototype.

I've long had an idea of how to create a machine that could extract energy from a system that doesn't have a difference in temperature, but the laws of thermodynamics tells me this is impossible. So I've never pursued it. That and the technology required for my idea does not yet exist.

text:
Jon L I don't really want to explain too much. We've worked on this for years. All inventions seem simple after they've been thought of. We never dreamed it would be so hard to take an idea and turn it into a machine. We've had to make everything from scratch. 
 But I'll tell you one thing, getting funding for a project like this is virtually impossible. Fake free energy devices are everywhere. But that also helps us keep ours hid. 
 We've had several thermodynamic professors to look at the details of the processes taking place and they can't find anything that debunks it. They are pretty excited about the opportunity to see something like this work. We are all thinking, why hasn't someone ever tried this. I'm sorry to spike your curiosity. But the people who are really working on break through devices do not have videos on YouTube or online articles. They want to keep it a secret so someone else doesn't steal the idea. That's why we don't hear much about the new batteries that's coming.

It is not just the replacement cost at 12 to 16 year mark that matters but will the replacement battery packs actually still be available at that age when these vehicles need them in masses. The situation can be like looking for a replacement battery for your iphone 1, even if the phone actually still works and looks really new.

Because all Teslas are connected to the factory via their computer if you do manage to replace it, they may prevent your Tesla from recognising it (similar to apple upgrades bricking or bloating your phone)

Older vehicles are not connected and most parts are still removeable with no computer to relearn and computer to monitor every move, disconnection, replacement etc. Those are actually able to be maintained DIY which manufacturers are now stamping out to increase control on their products life span. Car manufacturers are now following the phone industry and want to obtain the same control.

text:
Ignoring the EV religion apologetics for a moment, let's look at the battery manufacturer specification sheet.  As an example, this data is from LG's 18650 high discharge cells used in Teslas.  Additional information on charging from Battery University on the net is of particular interest.  Batteries, especially Li Ion, are not magic or supernatural in any way.

LG 18650 cells can be discharged up to 20 amps.  Impressive, but let's look at the finer print.  LG states that if you discharge the cells at 10 amps, their life is approximately 300 charge-discharge cycles.  If you hot rod the X with a heavy foot, the 20 amp discharge rate kills the cells faster at 200 charge-discharge cycles.  To make the cells last 8 to 20 years you'd need to park the car in a heated-cooled garage and hardly ever actually USE IT!  This is not my idea.  Go to batteryjunction.com and pick the LG 18650 bare (unprotected) cells which are $US7 each.  There's a click spot for LG's specification sheet on the webpage.  No mention of any religious or supernatural cell activity, though.  Heavy discharging Li-Ion cells results in the anode being PLATED by the Lithium metal!  Too much plating results in cells SHORTING and the accompanying FIRE AND OVERHEATING.  Keep drag racing that X.  Musk will always sell you a new car.
The most interesting thing Battery University shows about Li-Ion cells is their charging temperature range.  It states that Lithium Ion batteries must NEVER be charged below 32F (0C)!  Huh??  Does the supercharger heat up the -30F battery pack BEFORE charging starts?  How long does it take to bring 8000 cells up from -30F to +32F when it's -30F outside?  University warns you must never charge freezing Li-ion cells.  I must have missed that in the EV literature or bible.
It's not rocket science.  Li-Ion batteries are dangerous to charge and discharge.  Ask Samsung or Boeing what happens if you ignore the rules!

author: TheBrokenWorld

text: Neither of those statements is exactly true.  A ruptured fuel tank actually has very little chance of exploding or causing fire (of course, yes it happens).  However, a ruptured LiPo battery is guaranteed to cause a fire, and a cascade failure in seconds (it has happened to several Model S cars).  Doesn't pollute?  Half the pollution of ANY vehicle goes into its production, not to mention the lithium mining practices, and you would have to get your energy from "green" energy sources.  Add into that the necessary recycling of the batteries at end-of-life, a good thing, but still taking more energy and chemicals.  All told, an EV is estimated to be about 10% cleaner throughout its lifecycle (certainly not bad, but "doesn't pollute" is bs).  I'm for EVs, but don't kid yourself, there's a much broader picture.

text:
@Jay Besser Not really true either. Yes, there were a few fires with some early Model S, however, none of that was in seconds and in all cases the car warned the driver and they were able to safely park the car and get out before it burned out. Tesla has since introduced additional plating for the battery, which by the way is not LiPo either.

Yes, the upfront pollution of a BEV is currently higher than for an ICE car. However, after around 50.000 miles it is even on that score and after that it will be better mile for mile. 

Comparing pollution for energy production has been done, if one considers that all the energy needed for the BEV is produced by the same basic fossil fuels that an ICE car uses, including transportation, charging and discharging losses, it is still more efficient by a factor of minimum 2.5. If even part of the energy mix is renewable it becomes even better. A huge part of that is the average efficiency of modern car engines of at most 15% (yes, best case is 30 to 40%, however in only one very tiny spot on the power curve close to full power) versus 90+% for an electric motor, and if one compares that to stationary power supply by electric generation in power plants which easily reach 45% efficency, more if they use the heat for household and industrial heating it becomes clear while even the fossil fuel vs fossil fuel comparison comes out in favor of the BEV.

However, the energy mix turns towards more and more renewable energy in many countries and it is already cheaper to install solar generation capacity than building new coal plants on a per kWh basis.

text:
Pure battery powered cars are a dead end, who wants to break their journey for hours to recharge, Fuel cell or hybrid is, for the time being, the best option. 
As for lithium batteries, the fuel companies will not like it as they can't buy into their production as the Chinese have a monopoly on their production due to owning the source ore, even the Canadian stuff.
The new generation of rapid charge capacitors offer some benefits regarding re charging but topping up with actual fuel is sure to be the best way to keep drivers happy.
Pollution from cars is only really a problem in congested cities, so using a hybrid for town with the ability to petrol power your way on long journeys should sort that problem, 
One must be careful of listening too hard to the green brigade, their aim is to get rid of cars altogether and force us onto trains, so limited range battery powered cars are a good first step to that aim. The argument goes,  if drivers regularly do long journeys by train, as they can't use a car, they might wonder if it is worth having one in the first place. Not my idea of freedom.
Governments, certainly in Europe with their proposed IC engine ban, must be careful not to handover all means of motive power to our chinese friends(?)
Forgive the rambling, I haven't given it enough thought, yet.

author: Alexander Hamilton

text:
Dude. I own a Chevy Bolt EV. It does 0-60 in just over 6 seconds. That's hauling ass. But the part that blows people away is the 0-30 part. It's INSTANT. it SLAMS you back in the seat. My GF has politely asked me not to do that anymore, as it "makes me sick". The tires scream for relief at 20, 30, 40 mph. I live 80 miles away from where I work. When I get back, I still have 80 miles left to go, and I just plug in as soon as I get home anyways. If I can make it work, living 80 miles away from where I work, then anyone can. There's no excuse not to. If I need to go on a 'journey" of over 119 miles, I'll take a plane. Honestly, when was the last time you had to go someplace that was further than 119 miles. Never, that's when. Dude, a range of 119 miles is driving at an average of 60mph for two hours, turning around and heading back for two hours. People don't do that. If you really need to go further than that, it's for some special occasion, and you can always rent a car for the weekend or take a plane and really save yourself some time. Who wants to sit on a highway for more than 4 hours? Nobody. This car is the future AND the present. I'm living it, right now. As for your "lithium batteries is a Chinese monopoly" stuff, well, making China out to be the big bad guy is an old FOX NEWS/ Donald Trump ruse used to get people like you to fear "Them". It works, so they use it all the time. Lithium is a very common element that is easily extracted, mostly using water and the sun. You aughtta YouTube it. It mostly comes from the country of Chile, but there are large quantities of it in Nevada, which is why TESLA is located there. Also, Lithium is indestructible, it being a basic element, so it can be recycled indefinitely. Look, I get it, you're scared. Don't be. You should be proud of the American car manufacturers like GM and TESLA, right here in California. China hasn't come up with anything like a CHEVY BOLT 238 miles, or TESLA with its' truly AWESOME acceleration, the fastest mass-produced sedan in history. Europe is still piddling around with ranges that just eek over 110 miles. Chevy just kicked ass with the BOLT: 238 EPA, (and most people get better than that without even trying. I'm one of 'em) EMBRACE THE PRESENT. It's EXCITING. Let go of the oil-stained, polluted past. You're living in an amazing time. 

Pollution is a problem for the whole world. We humans have been using the thin (2 miles or so) of breathable air we have on earth as a trash can for over 100 years. We've polluted it pretty bad. CO2 stays in the air for about 100 years. I bought an EV because its' the responsible thing to do. I'm a teacher, and when the kids learn that I drive 80 miles to work every day, and they can see my Chevy BOLT EV sitting in the parking lot, right out the window, they know that driving an EV a long distance in an EV is doable, a reality, actually. Convincing you is probably impossible. But the younger generation is growing up in a different time than when you and me grew up. They're not afraid of EV's they think TESLAs are cool. Times are changing whether you like it or not. May as well enjoy it.
author: Alexander Hamilton

text: Robert Harrigan+ how do you know what distances we drive? how can you say that we have never driven 119 miles away from where we live? do you think that maybe we don't want to spend our whole life inside our city? maybe we like to take small road trips every now and then, or need to travel for business? 119 miles really isn't that far, you're also not taking traffic and speed into account or what appliances might be running inside the car. l know somebody who drives from 50-200 miles to work, and spends hours in the car stuck in traffic. what if it's a hot day and you're stuck in traffic with the AC on high? all you're doing is just draining your battery and you aren't even moving. not to mention the more you drive, the faster you'll need to spend 1000's of dollars on a new battery bank. also it takes hours to recharge the car so if you need to go somewhere after you just drained your battery then you're shit out of luck and you'll have to wait a few hours. also how is this person l know supposed to put ladder racks and tools in a little electric car? this person l know, needs a truck/van. this person l know also likes to tow thing cross country which you can't do with an electric car because they don't have the range or the horse power. l know electric cars are quick and zippy, but they are not powerful by any means. you can only put so much strain on an electric motor before you burn it out. your typical small block V8 can tow 1000's of pounds cross country without even breaking a sweat.
author: Electronics For Fun

text: I drove from DFW to Indy over the weekend for a funeral that happened at the last minute.  Why drive and not fly?  The difference is $150 in gas (hotel is a wash) vs. $950 for plane tickets and another $80 for a rental car.  Just because you don't do something, don't assume others don't, it makes you look foolish.
author: James Menefee

text:
"Honestly, when was the last time you had to go someplace that was further than 119 miles. Never, that's when." when l was a little kid we used to drive out every month to tucson so we could see some relatives. we lived in phoenix and it was like 125-130 miles away. we aren't talking the city area of tucson, we're talking out in the boonies where the nearest store is over 50 miles away and all you can see is open desert with a few houses in between. and honestly if you were out there driving an electric car you would probably get shot, since just about everybody there has a truck of some sort. sorry but driving is easier, also l don't think there are flights between tucson and phoenix, even if there were it is still cheaper and faster to drive there.

"If you really need to go further than that, it's for some special occasion, and you can always rent a car for the weekend or take a plane and really save yourself some time." if l need to rent another car because the car l own isn't good enough... then the car l own isn't good enough. l don't know why you think we have all this money to be renting cars and taking planes everywhere, while the car we own just sits in the garage. if you want to use an electric car for driving around town then fine, but l need a car that doesn't have to stop and take a breath for the rest of the day.

"Who wants to sit on a highway for more than 4 hours? Nobody." if you live in california then you don't get a choice.

"making China out to be the big bad guy is an old FOX NEWS/ Donald Trump ruse used to get people like you to fear "Them"." no it's real, look on the bottom of a radio or on the back of your TV or on the bottom of your computer, it all says "made in china" which is bad. we're giving china all of the jobs, while millions of americans are on welfare and sucking the economy dry.

"You should be proud of the American car manufacturers like GM and TESLA, right here in California." the thing that gets me is that you used california and american is the same sentence. california is only an american state on paper, on a social level it's a whole other country, that the rest of this country hates. it's really sad to see california become such a hell hole, it used to be one of the most american states in the country... now everything is illegal here. you could literally be breaking the law just by sitting on a bench, it's fucking ridiculous.

l am not saying electric cars are bad, l am just saying that gassers are better. they're more fun, they're easier to work on yourself and they make great noises. not to mention that they are more practical. 

"May as well enjoy it." how can l enjoy it if l don't like it? l have ZERO interest in electric cars. l'm and old mopar kind of guy.
author: Electronics For Fun

text: Kevin Kellner: In my city the power is 100% green. The US average is 30.4% coal power in 2016, and dropping. Most new power projects are green. I'm glad you hate coal so much though, it is nasty.  You seem to be sarcastic, but the Tesla cells do not contain any rare earths. If you think they do, then you probably spend too much time on nutter sites. Lithium cells have actually very low toxicity. Lead batteries and alkaline batteries are quite toxic however, stay off the nutter sites! Lithium cells contain valuable nickel, and so will all be recycled. Telsawill recycle old cells at their Gigafactory, which is also designed to have 100% green power supply. I hate to tell you, but your nutter sites have made you less informed.

text: Harsh Kalra so you're telling me that all of the toxic chemicals and the production of said chemicals that go into making battery's are totally not harmful to the environment at all
author: Thomas Goettsche

text: No I am not saying that. I am contesting your claim that the production of electric cars is more polluting than ICE cars can ever be in their lifetime. It's a ridiculous statement. While some of the materials that go into make the batteries are pollutant, they are in no way more polluting than use of fossil fuel. The entire process of extracting and refining petroleum is as polluting if not more. Plus when you burn that fuel in an highly inefficient engine you get even more pollution, which is released in the air of the cities that we live in, right in front of our noses in the air we breathe. Plus fossil fuel and ICE are at the end of the technological life cycle, they can't be improved much. But Electric cars and batteries are at the beginning. Already new battery technologies are coming up that will cut the use of many toxic chemicals in their production.
author: Harsh Kalra
